1818342.xml.text: A front-page article yesterday about the difficulty in filling city manager jobs misspelled the surname of the longtime manager of Charlotte, N.C., who announced her retirement. She is Pam Syfert, not Seyfert.
1818342.xml.title: Corrections

1822451.xml.text: An obituary on Jan. 2 about Sydney Wooderson, a British runner who once held the world record for the mile, misstated the name of the federation that did not recognize a 1938 record for the 4:04.4 mile set by Glenn Cunningham at Dartmouth. It was the International Amateur Athletic Federation, not Athletics.  The obituary also referred incompletely to the reasons given by the federation for rejecting the record. It did not recognize any indoor records until 1987, and it has never recognized indoor records set on tracks with laps longer than 220 yards; the Dartmouth track was 264 yards a lap. (As the obituary noted, the federation also rejected the record because Cunningham used four different quarter milers to pace him.)
1822451.xml.title: Corrections

1821944.xml.text: An article on Jan. 14 about David Byrne and his song cycle based on the life of Imelda Marcos, the former first lady of the Philippines, misidentified the ethnicity of a singer in the production. Ganda Suthivarakom is of Thai-Chinese descent; she is not Filipino.
1821944.xml.title: Corrections

1816772.xml.text: A picture in Business Day on Thursday of the home of Robert L. Nardelli, who was ousted as chairman and chief executive of Home Depot, carried an incorrect credit. It was by Chris Rank of Bloomberg News, not by Home Depot.
1816772.xml.title: Corrections

1819921.xml.text: An article last Friday about $250,000 second homes around the nation misstated a lake open to the public near Victorville, Calif., a popular second-home area. It is Silverwood Lake, which is in a state recreation area, not Lake Arrowhead, which is private.
1819921.xml.title: Corrections

1819708.xml.text: A television review in Weekend on Jan. 5 about the new reality show ''Living With Ed,'' on HGTV, misidentified the car that Ed Begley Jr. drives. It is a Toyota converted to run on electricity, not a Volkswagen.
1819708.xml.title: Corrections

1822210.xml.text: An article on the front page of Arts & Leisure today about the composer Ennio Morricone incorrectly lists Enya among the performers on a tribute album to be released in February, ''We All Love Ennio Morricone.'' She does not appear on the album.
1822210.xml.title: Corrections

1819711.xml.text: Because of an editing error, an article in Science Times on Tuesday about the appearance of a new island as a result of glacial melting in Greenland referred incorrectly to a region where another such island has appeared. Svalbard, off Norway, is an archipelago, not an island.
1819711.xml.title: Corrections

1817666.xml.text: An art review on Thursday about the exhibition ''South Bronx Contemporary: Longwood Arts Project's 25th Anniversary,'' at Hostos Community College in the Bronx, omitted a curator. The wall of art hung salon-style was organized by Edwin Ramoran under the title ''Everyday Is Like Sunday''; it is not part of ''Iconoclasm,'' organized by Eddie Torres and hanging in the same room.  A picture caption with the review misstated the given name of a former director of the Longwood Arts Project who is also one of the curators of the show. As noted in the review, he is Fred Wilson, not Frank.
1817666.xml.title: Corrections

1817668.xml.text: A picture caption in The Arts yesterday with an article about Christopher Wheeldon's new New York-based classical dance company and its possible impact on New York City Ballet and American Ballet Theater referred imprecisely to the ballerina Alexandra Ansanelli, who was shown in a performance with City Ballet. While she was with that company when the picture was taken, in 2002, she is now a member of the Royal Ballet in London.
1817668.xml.title: Corrections

1819123.xml.text: An article in Thursday Styles on Dec. 7 about holiday music in retail stores and an article in Dining on Jan. 3 about the debate over playing music in restaurants misstated the name of a music consulting company that sells audio systems and programming to such businesses. It is DMX -- not Digital Music Express or Digital Music Xperience.
1819123.xml.title: Corrections

1817863.xml.text: An article in Business Day on Saturday about the energy efficient ways of the Japanese misstated the amount of energy consumed in Japan and the United States as measured in tons of oil per person. Japan consumed the energy equivalent of 2.8 tons of oil per person in 2004, not 2.8 million tons. Likewise, the United States consumed 5.4 tons of oil per person, not 5.4 million tons. The article also referred imprecisely to the output from a home fuel cell used by a Japanese homeowner, Kiminobu Kimura. The cell produces one kilowatt of power per hour; not one kilowatt per hour.
1817863.xml.title: Corrections

1816155.xml.text: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about an investigation into the possibility that banks are luring hedge funds as tenants in order to solicit their trading business misstated the nature of a request made by the Massachusetts secretary of state, William F. Galvin, to UBS, the Swiss bank. While Mr. Galvin has requested information from UBS, he has not issued a subpoena. UBS is cooperating with the inquiry.
1816155.xml.title: Corrections

1819302.xml.text: An article in Business Day on Thursday about an increase in Wal-Mart employees enrolled in a company health plan misstated the number of workers who signed up during an enrollment period this fall. It was about 45,000 workers, not 82,000.
1819302.xml.title: Corrections

1818667.xml.text: An article on Dec. 31 about winter events in St. Petersburg, Russia, referred incorrectly to the Seventh Symphony of Shostakovich. He composed part of it as shells fell on the city (then known as Leningrad); he did not conduct it. The article also referred incorrectly to meters in taxis there. Taxis typically have meters, but they are not always used.  The article also referred incorrectly to sleighs used in a popular park. The sleighs are pulled by single horses; they are not troikas, which are pulled by three horses.  And a picture caption misidentified a large yellow neo-Classical building. It is the General Staff Building, which is part of the Hermitage palace complex; it is not the Hermitage.
1818667.xml.title: Corrections

1816766.xml.text: An article last Saturday about mourning for Gerald R. Ford in California misstated the year he moved there after leaving the White House. It was 1977, not 1976. A correction in this space on Wednesday misspelled the name of the city where the Ford family lived. It is Palm Desert, not Palm Dessert.
1816766.xml.title: Corrections

1817662.xml.text: An article in Business Day on Dec. 30 about energy efficiency and carbon dioxide reductions misstated the relative savings a driver could achieve by switching to a large sport utility vehicle that got an additional two miles per gallon compared with switching to a car that got two more miles per gallon. Savings in the large S.U.V. are two and a half times larger, not three and a half times.
1817662.xml.title: Corrections

1821075.xml.text: An article on Friday about the Pentagon's new rules for military commissions to try prisoners held at Guantánamo, Cuba, on terrorism charges, misstated the reasons cited by the Supreme Court when it struck down the Bush administration's original plans for the commissions. And a correction in this space yesterday repeated the error. The court ruled last year in Hamdan v. Rumsfeld that the initial procedures established for the commissions were unauthorized by federal statute and violated international law. It did not rule that the commissions themselves were unconstitutional.
1821075.xml.title: Corrections

1818076.xml.text: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a secure telephone that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg uses in his Manhattan town house rendered incorrectly a quotation from him. The mayor said he had occasionally received calls on the secure line asking ''did I want to subscribe to a particular magazine, buy an insurance policy or some other such ridiculous thing.'' He did not say the callers asked ''did I want to subscribe to a ridiculous magazine, buy an insurance policy or some other such particular thing.''
1818076.xml.title: Corrections

1819121.xml.text: A report in the Observatory column of Science Times last Tuesday about the impact of large herbivores on ecosystems misstated the middle initial of the lead researcher, a doctoral student at Stanford. He is Robert M. Pringle, not Robert W.
1819121.xml.title: Corrections

1817160.xml.text: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about art insurance misstated the location of the New England Brokerage Corporation that employs Brian Frasca, an insurance broker who gave examples of coverage for artwork. It is in Greenwich, Conn. -- not Providence, R.I., where a different company of the same name is located.
1817160.xml.title: Corrections

1820938.xml.text: An article on Friday about the Pentagon's new rules for military commissions to try prisoners held at Guantánamo, Cuba, on terrorism charges, misstated the reasons cited by the Supreme Court when it struck down the Bush administration's original plans for the commissions. The court ruled last year in Hamdan v. Rumsfeld that the initial procedures established for the commissions were unconstitutional.  Correction:  January 24, 2007, Wednesday  An article on Friday about the Pentagon's new rules for military commissions to try prisoners held at Guantánamo, Cuba, on terrorism charges, misstated the reasons cited by the Supreme Court when it struck down the Bush administration's original plans for the commissions. And a correction in this space yesterday repeated the error. The court ruled last year in Hamdan v. Rumsfeld that the initial procedures established for the commissions were unauthorized by federal statute and violated international law. It did not rule that the commissions themselves were unconstitutional.
1820938.xml.title: Corrections

1822441.xml.text: A picture caption on Wednesday about construction of a foundation wall at the World Trade Center site misstated the total number of steel cages that will be used to reinforce the wall. There will be 64, not 63.
1822441.xml.title: Corrections

1819125.xml.text: An obituary by The Associated Press on Jan. 6 about the character actor Frank Campanella misstated his relationship to the actor Joseph Campanella. Frank was Joseph's older brother, not a younger brother.
1819125.xml.title: Corrections

1818077.xml.text: An article on Saturday about a controversy over a national sweepstakes awarding a $25,000 savings bond to the first American baby born in 2007 gave an erroneous birth weight in some copies for a Chinese-American girl, born in Manhattan, who was disqualified because her mother was not a legal resident. The girl, Yuki Lin, weighed 6.5 pounds, not 6.5 ounces. (The sponsor of the sweepstakes, Toys ''R'' Us, has since reversed its decision and awarded Yuki and two other babies born shortly after midnight $25,000 each.)
1818077.xml.title: Corrections

1816351.xml.text: A headline in Business Day yesterday about a lawsuit brought by Intertainer, a digital media company, against Apple Computer, Google and Napster misstated the nature of the litigation. It involves a patent, not a copyright.
1816351.xml.title: Corrections

1818081.xml.text: A report in the World Business Briefing column last Thursday about the start up of Ironshore Insurance in Bermuda carried an incorrect credit. It was by Bloomberg News, not The Associated Press.
1818081.xml.title: Corrections

1821943.xml.text: An Art entry last Sunday in the Week Ahead report gave an incomplete title for an exhibition at the Museum of Arts and Design. It is ''Radical Lace and Subversive Knitting,'' not ''Lace and Subversive Knitting.''
1821943.xml.title: Corrections

1816162.xml.text: A music column yesterday about pop songs on war misstated the title of the song, about a lover killed in combat, that starts the Norah Jones album due out this month. It is ''Wish I Could'' -- not ''Thinking About You,'' which is the title of another song on the album.
1816162.xml.title: Corrections

1820108.xml.text: A report in the baseball roundup on Thursday about the status of the Bay Area Laboratory Co-Operative steroids investigation misstated the number of men who have pleaded guilty and been sentenced in the case. It is five, not four. The article also gave an outdated academic position for Peter Keane, who commented on the outlook for the case. He is a law professor at Golden Gate University School of Law in San Francisco; he is no longer the dean of the law school.
1820108.xml.title: Corrections

1821902.xml.text: The Explorer column on Jan. 14 about Angel Falls in Venezuela, misidentified the type of airplane flown by Jimmie Angel, who survived a crash landing there in the 1930s. It was a radial-engine monoplane -- not a turboprop, which was not developed until the 1940s.
1821902.xml.title: Corrections

1816356.xml.text: An art entry in the Listings pages of Weekend on Friday misstated the surname of the artist whose ''Urban Air Scrubber'' was at the Tribes Gallery on East Third Street in the East Village. He is William Meyer, not Brent. (Adam Brent is the artist who made another work that was on display.)
1816356.xml.title: Corrections

1818352.xml.text: An article on Sunday about separatist rebel attacks in the northeast Indian state of Assam misstated its precise location. Assam borders several other Indian states and the kingdom of Bhutan; it does not border Myanmar.
1818352.xml.title: Corrections

1819702.xml.text: An article on Jan. 4 about Delores Pryce, a Queens woman whose youngest daughter has health problems and who received help from The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund to help pay an electricity bill, referred incorrectly to New Alternatives for Children, a program that helps families with medically fragile children. (The error was repeated in an article on Jan. 5 about Dorcas Acheampong, a Bronx woman who received help from the fund to help pay her rent.) Although it is a member agency of the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, it is not run by the federation.
1819702.xml.title: Corrections

1821332.xml.text: A front-page article on Friday about criticism of Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, Iran's president, by Iranian religious authorities over his involvement in the country's nuclear program misstated the connection between Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, the supreme leader, and Jomhouri-Eslami, a newspaper that has rebuked Mr. Ahmadinejad. (The error was repeated in an article about Iran on Tuesday.) Ayatollah Khamenei owned the newspaper until 1989, when he became supreme leader and transferred ownership to Massih Mohajeri, a conservative politician. However, the newspaper still reflects Ayatollah Khamenei's views.
1821332.xml.title: Corrections

1818665.xml.text: The Check In/Check Out column last Sunday about Hotel 17 in Manhattan misstated its neighborhood. The hotel, at 225 East 17th Street, is east of Union Square; it is not on the Lower East Side.
1818665.xml.title: Corrections

1819705.xml.text: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about General Electric's purchase of Smiths Group's aerospace business misstated G.E.'s percentage of ownership of Smiths GE Detection, a joint venture between the companies. G.E. will own 36 percent, not 46 percent.
1819705.xml.title: Corrections

1818982.xml.text: The cover review in the Book Review today, about Martin Amis's novel ''House of Meetings,'' misstates the relationship between the unnamed narrator and Venus, the young woman he addresses throughout. She is his stepdaughter, not his daughter.
1818982.xml.title: Corrections

1822660.xml.text: A classical music entry in the Listings pages of Weekend on Jan. 19 misstated the history of the performance in New York of ''Il Signor Bruschino,'' by Rossini, which the Gotham Chamber Orchestra is performing through Saturday. The Gotham Chamber Orchestra's production is the first professional staging of the work in New York since 1933, not the first staging since then. (The error was repeated in a Week Ahead entry in Arts & Leisure on Jan. 21, in the Listings pages of Weekend on Friday and in a review of a performance on Saturday.)
1822660.xml.title: Corrections

1819503.xml.text: An article in Business Day on Jan. 8 about announcements by Sony and Microsoft regarding sales of their latest game consoles misstated the price of the high-end configuration of Microsoft Xbox 360. It is $399, not $499.
1819503.xml.title: Corrections

1817234.xml.text: The Habitats article last Sunday about the art-filled apartment on the Upper West Side of Violy McCausland and Frederico Sève misspelled the city in Colombia where McCausland was born. It is Barranquilla, not Baranquilla.
1817234.xml.title: Corrections

1822438.xml.text: An article on Jan. 21 about Mexico's extradition of drug traffickers to the United States incorrectly described a November 2005 decision by Mexico's Supreme Court that cleared the way for the extraditions. The court ruled that extraditions could proceed if the accused faced a possible life sentence without parole, which Mexican courts had previously held violated the country's constitution. The court did not overturn the prohibition on extraditions in which the accused would face the death penalty. (None of the accused drug traffickers extradited on Jan. 19 face the death penalty, Justice Department officials say.)  The article also misstated the number of people extradited. It was 15, not 21.
1822438.xml.title: Corrections

1816982.xml.text: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about a film based on Khaled Hosseini's novel ''The Kite Runner'' reversed the identifications for two men involved in the production, based on information provided by the studio. The novelist was on the left, and the director, Marc Forster, was on the right.
1816982.xml.title: Corrections

1819710.xml.text: A music column on Saturday about a new album by the Smithereens (''Meet the Smithereens!'') that reproduces the song lineup and much of the arrangements on ''Meet the Beatles!'' misidentified the Smithereens' lead guitarist, whose solos were compared to George Harrison's. Although Pat DiNizio does play guitar in the band, it is Jim Babjak who plays lead.
1819710.xml.title: Corrections

1816948.xml.text: A map with the 36 Hours column on Dec. 24 about Paris incorrectly located the Champs-Élysées. The avenue runs from the Arc de Triomphe to the Place de la Concorde, not to the Place de la République. A corrected map can be found online at nytimes.com/travel.
1816948.xml.title: Corrections

1820101.xml.text: An article in Business Day on Dec. 29 about concessions that investors in oil and gas fields have given the Russia government misspelled the name of one gas field involved. (The error also appeared in articles last year on Nov. 8, Oct. 11, Sept. 23 and March 22.) It is Kovykta, not Kovytka.
1820101.xml.title: Corrections

1820111.xml.text: An entry in the Spare Times for Children listing in Weekend yesterday, about the ''Brain Games'' exhibition at the Children's Museum of Manhattan, misstated the days the museum is open. It is open Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m., not Tuesdays through Fridays.
1820111.xml.title: Corrections

1816597.xml.text: An article on Wednesday about the funeral of former President Gerald R. Ford drew an erroneous comparison between Chelsea Clinton and Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice, who sat next to each other. Ms. Rice received degrees from the University of Denver and Notre Dame. She is not an alumna of Stanford University, where Ms. Clinton received a bachelor's degree. (Ms . Rice is a former Stanford provost.)
1816597.xml.title: Corrections

1822834.xml.text: The Antiques column in Weekend on Friday, about an auction of silver that had been owned by the First Church in Salem, in Massachusetts, attributed an erroneous distinction to the church. The Marble Collegiate Church in Manhattan, founded in 1628, is the oldest continuously operating Protestant congregation in the United States -- not the First Church in Salem, which was founded a year later.
1822834.xml.title: Corrections

1819954.xml.text: A sports article on Wednesday about the New Orleans Saints' financial situation gave the wrong day for the team's playoff game last week against the Philadelphia Eagles. The game was played on Saturday, not Sunday.
1819954.xml.title: Corrections

1822835.xml.text: An art review in Weekend on Jan. 19 about two shows at the International Center of Photography in Manhattan, featuring the works of Henri Cartier-Bresson and Martin Munkacsi, referred imprecisely to some of the countries Munkacsi visited on assignment for the German publisher Ullstein. Algeria and Egypt are part of Africa; he did not visit them in addition to Africa.
1822835.xml.title: Corrections

1816947.xml.text: An article on Dec. 24 about visiting Washington, D.C., in winter misstated the hours and holiday closings for three museums. The National Portrait Gallery and the Smithsonian American Art Museum are open from 11:30 a.m. to 7 p.m. daily -- not until 9 p.m. on Thursdays and Fridays. They close only one day a year -- on Dec. 25; they do not close on Dec. 24, 25 and 26. The National Gallery of Art closes each year on Dec. 25 and Jan. 1, not just on Christmas Day.
1816947.xml.title: Corrections

1816166.xml.text: An obituary on Thursday about former President Gerald R. Ford misstated his relationship to the three brothers with whom he was raised. They were his half-brothers, not his stepbrothers.  Correction:  January 6, 2007, Saturday  An article last Saturday about mourning for Gerald R. Ford in California misstated the year he moved there after leaving the White House. It was 1977, not 1976. A correction in this space on Wednesday misspelled the name of the city where the Ford family lived. It is Palm Desert, not Palm Dessert.
1816166.xml.title: Corrections

1818079.xml.text: A chart on the Street Scene page of Business Day last Thursday that listed the leading merger and acquisition advisers misstated the value of the deals in 2006. For Goldman, Sachs, the sector leader, it was $1.088 trillion, not $108.8 trillion. For the industry as a whole, the value of the deals was $3.805 trillion, not $380.5 trillion. A corrected chart can be found at nytimes.com/business.
1818079.xml.title: Corrections

1821333.xml.text: A front-page article on Friday about criticism of Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, Iran's president, by Iranian religious authorities over his involvement in the country's nuclear program misstated the connection between Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, the supreme leader, and Jomhouri-Eslami, a newspaper that has rebuked Mr. Ahmadinejad. (The error was repeated in an article about Iran on Tuesday.) Ayatollah Khamenei owned the newspaper until 1989, when he became supreme leader and transferred ownership to Massih Mohajeri, a conservative politician. However, the newspaper still reflects Ayatollah Khamenei's views.
1821333.xml.title: Corrections

1819704.xml.text: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Saturday about a meeting between the United States trade representative, Susan C. Schwab, and the head of the World Trade Organization, Pascal Lamy, misstated the date of Mr. Lamy's discussion with Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain about the restart of global trade negotiations. It had already been held, on Jan. 9; it was not scheduled for Tuesday.
1819704.xml.title: Corrections

1819308.xml.text: A picture caption in The Arts yesterday with a music review about the Dicapo Opera Theater misidentified the production shown. It was ''Messa di Gloria'' -- not ''Le Villi,'' which was the other work on the program.
1819308.xml.title: Corrections

1819700.xml.text: An article on Tuesday about intestinal surgeries that a Spanish newspaper said had been performed on Fidel Castro referred incorrectly to peritonitis, a serious condition that the newspaper said had afflicted Mr. Castro after one of the surgeries. Peritonitis is an inflammation of the lining of the abdominal cavity, called the peritoneum; it is not an inflammation of the stomach lining.
1819700.xml.title: Corrections

1817667.xml.text: A music review on Jan. 1 about Gov't Mule and Los Lobos, at the Beacon Theater, misstated the surname of a member of Los Lobos. He is Cesar Rosas, not Rojas.
1817667.xml.title: Corrections

1819492.xml.text: An article in Business Day yesterday about Johnnie M. Burton, who runs the Interior Department's troubled program to collect royalties on oil and gas pumped on public lands, misstated the circumstances under which Gov. Jim Geringer of Wyoming, who had named Ms. Burton to run the state's Department of Revenue, left office. Wyoming term-limit laws prevented Mr. Geringer, a Republican, from running for re-election in 2002; he was not ''ousted'' by voters.
1819492.xml.title: Corrections

1816775.xml.text: An art review in Weekend on Dec. 15 about Queens International 2006, at the Queens Museum of Art, misspelled the given name and surname of the artist whose embroidered panels explore female sexuality, and a correction in this space on Wednesday repeated the misspelling of her surname. She is Blanka Amezkua, not Blanca Amezcua.
1816775.xml.title: Corrections

1817859.xml.text: An article last Wednesday about prominent people who attended the funeral of former President Gerald R. Ford referred incorrectly to George Allen, Republican of Virginia. His Senate term ended at noon last Wednesday. At the time he arrived for the funeral, he was not a former lawmaker.
1817859.xml.title: Corrections

1816983.xml.text: A pop music list on Dec. 24 of the best albums of 2006 omitted a songwriter. The songs on ''Yellow House,'' from Grizzly Bear, were written by Daniel Rossen as well as the group's founder, Edward Droste.
1816983.xml.title: Corrections

1816156.xml.text: A front-page article on Monday about American military members who have died in the Iraq war misstated the number of crewmates who survived an explosion that killed a tank driver, Specialist Jordan W. Hess. There were three, not four.
1816156.xml.title: Corrections

1822439.xml.text: The credit for pictures last Monday with the continuation of a front-page article about a whooping cough scare at Dartmouth-Hitchcock Medical Center omitted the photographer's surname. He is Jon Gilbert Fox.
1822439.xml.title: Corrections

1818490.xml.text: A report in the World Briefing column on Friday misstated the given name of a banker arrested on suspicion of ordering the killing of the deputy of Russia's central bank. He is Aleksei Y. Frenkel, not Andrei.
1818490.xml.title: Corrections

1819707.xml.text: Because of an editing error, a report in the N.B.A. roundup in some copies last Thursday, about the Toronto Raptors' 90-77 victory over the Milwaukee Bucks, misstated the team that Toronto tied for the lead in the Atlantic Division as a result. It was the Nets, not the Knicks.
1819707.xml.title: Corrections

1816768.xml.text: A picture caption with an article last Saturday about the Supreme Court Documentary History Project reversed the names of two of the project's editors. Robert Frankel was standing at left and Stephen Tull in the middle, next to another editor, Natalie Wexler.
1816768.xml.title: Corrections

1816767.xml.text: An article last Saturday about mourning for Gerald R. Ford in California misstated the year he moved there after leaving the White House. It was 1977, not 1976. A correction in this space on Wednesday misspelled the name of the city where the Ford family lived. It is Palm Desert, not Palm Dessert.
1816767.xml.title: Corrections

1820099.xml.text: An article on Jan. 6 about a police officer in Madison, Conn., who is accused of stealing lobster meat and shrimp from a local seafood restaurant, referred incorrectly to the town's location. Madison is 20 miles east -- not south -- of New Haven.
1820099.xml.title: Corrections

1820105.xml.text: A chart in Business Day yesterday with an article about the chief executive of the Mesa Air Group referred incorrectly to the company's revenue for the years 2002 through 2006. It was in billions, not millions. A corrected graphic can be found at nytimes.com/business.
1820105.xml.title: Corrections

1816164.xml.text: A picture caption in The Arts on Thursday with an article about Dance Theater Workshop's program to provide subsidized rehearsal space outside Manhattan carried an erroneous credit. While the picture of the dancer Miguel Gutierrez was indeed by Julieta Cervantes, the picture of his rehearsal space in Woodside, Queens, was by Todd Richmond.
1816164.xml.title: Corrections

1815967.xml.text: Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about the continuing political gridlock in Lebanon misstated the action taken in November by opposition ministers aligned with Hezbollah. They quit the cabinet, not the Parliament.
1815967.xml.title: Corrections

1818492.xml.text: A front-page article on Sunday about the power of committee leaders in Congress misspelled the given name of a former Democratic chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee. He was Wilbur Mills of Arkansas, not Wilber.
1818492.xml.title: Corrections

1817858.xml.text: An article yesterday about the presidential campaign of Mitt Romney, the former governor of Massachusetts, misidentified the home state of Mike Huckabee, another former governor who is also a prospective Republican candidate for president. He was the governor of Arkansas, not Arizona.
1817858.xml.title: Corrections

1821942.xml.text: A review last Sunday of Tony Trischka's album ''Double Banjo Bluegrass Spectacular'' in the Playlist column misidentified a guest banjoist, Alison Brown. She is formerly of the group Union Station; she is no longer a member.
1821942.xml.title: Corrections

1819959.xml.text: An obituary on Jan. 11 by The New York Times Regional Newspapers about James C. Weeks, a former president and chief operating officer of The New York Times Regional Media Group, incorrectly described his postgraduate education. He was a graduate of the Program for Management Development at the Harvard Business School -- not a recipient of a master's degree in marketing from the University of Florida, where he earned his undergraduate degree. The obituary also misspelled the given name of his wife. She is Toney Weeks, not Toni.
1819959.xml.title: Corrections

1818496.xml.text: An obituary on Dec. 29 about Edwin Edwards, the banker who helped bring a currency trading scandal at Citibank to light, gave an erroneous name in some copies for the investment bank for which he later worked. It was Stephens Inc., not Stephen Inc.
1818496.xml.title: Corrections

1817860.xml.text: An article and headline yesterday about the death of a disturbed man who apparently went into cardiac arrest after being shot with a Taser stun gun during a struggle with New York City police officers misidentified his borough of residence in some copies. He was from Brooklyn, not Queens.
1817860.xml.title: Corrections

1817658.xml.text: An article on Sunday about marines charged in the killing of 24 Iraqis in the village of Haditha in November 2005 misidentified the Pennyslvania hometown of one marine because of information provided by his lawyer. The marine, Lance Cpl. Justin Sharratt, is from Canonsburg, not Carbondale. (The error also appeared in articles on Dec. 6 and Dec. 22.)
1817658.xml.title: Corrections

1822831.xml.text: An article in Business Day last Wednesday about the possibility of Rupert Murdoch joining the Chandler family's bid for the Tribune Company misstated the source of a comment by Alfonse D'Amato, the former Republican senator from New York, about the merits of such a move by Mr. Murdoch. Mr. D'Amato's comment was from a column in The Long Island Business News, not Newsday.
1822831.xml.title: Corrections

1818349.xml.text: A ''Back of the Envelope'' chart on the Street Scene page of Business Day last Friday, about the leading law firms for mergers and acquisitions in 2006, misstated in the summary the 2005 ranking of this year's top firm, Sullivan & Cromwell. It finished third; Freshfields Bruckhaus Deringer was first.
1818349.xml.title: Corrections

1822211.xml.text: A picture caption on the front page of today's Travel section, referring to the 36 Hours column on Madrid, misidentifies the building shown. It is the library of the Reina Sofía Museum, not the Mercado Fuencarral, a boutique shopping center.
1822211.xml.title: Corrections

1818350.xml.text: The Connections column on Monday, about music in the films of Alfred Hitchcock, misspelled the surname of a composer who worked with him. He was Miklos Rozsa, not Rosza.
1818350.xml.title: Corrections

1822664.xml.text: An obituary on Jan. 19 about Ron Carey, a comic actor, referred incorrectly to the character he played on the situation comedy ''Barney Miller.'' He was a uniformed policeman, not a ''plainclothes cop.'' The obituary also included an outdated title for a television show that Mr. Carey appeared on in 1969 and 1970. By that time, it was known as ''The Ed Sullivan Show,'' not ''Toast of the Town.''
1822664.xml.title: Corrections

1820096.xml.text: An article on Thursday about a strain of avian flu found in Egypt that is resistant to oseltamivir, the chief weapon against the virus, misspelled the name of another drug that remains effective against it. It is zanamivir (sold as Relenza), not zanamir.
1820096.xml.title: Corrections

1817864.xml.text: A music column on Saturday about the View, a Scottish band from Dundee that made its American debut last week in New York, misstated the name of a Dundee suburb that one of its songs apparently refers to. It is Broughty Ferry, not Broughton Ferry.
1817864.xml.title: Corrections

1816352.xml.text: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about Web sites that offer unfiltered video clips misstated the type of aircraft shown attacking Taliban forces in Afghanistan in one such video. It was an A-10 Thunderbolt, not an A-20 Havoc.
1816352.xml.title: Corrections

1816358.xml.text: A front-page article yesterday about an Iraqi government investigation of the abusive behavior at the execution of Saddam Hussein, including the unauthorized cellphone camera recording of it, misstated the account of a witness who said he saw two others there holding cellphone cameras aloft to record Mr. Hussein's final moments. While the witness, Munkith al-Faroun, a prosecutor at Mr. Hussein's trial, said both of the others were officials, he did not identify one of them as Mowaffak al-Rubaie, the national security adviser. Mr. Rubaie, who could not be reached for comment in the article, said yesterday that he had handed his cellphone to security officials an hour before the hanging and had not recorded it.
1816358.xml.title: Corrections

1820109.xml.text: A Sports of The Times column on Wednesday, about Muhammad Ali's 65th birthday, rendered incorrectly an antiwar quotation from him in the 1960s. He said, ''I ain't got no quarrel with them Vietcong'' -- not ''I got nothin' against them Vietcong.''
1820109.xml.title: Corrections

1819502.xml.text: An article in Business Day on Friday about the role that employment contracts play in the large severance payouts for executives gave an incorrect spelling in some copies for the name of a company that the chief executive of Wrigley, William D. Perez, mentioned during a discussion of contracts. It is S. C. Johnson, not S. C. Johnston.
1819502.xml.title: Corrections

1818698.xml.text: An article on Dec. 31 about Mike Myers's absence from the big screen while movies with Jim Carrey and other comedians appear regularly misstated Mr. Carrey's role in ''Lemony Snicket's A Series of Unfortunate Events.'' He played Count Olaf, not the title character.
1818698.xml.title: Corrections

1821552.xml.text: A sports article by The Associated Press last Friday about the Bob Hope Chrysler Classic misidentified the winner of the Texas Open in September. It was Eric Axley -- not Justin Rose, who shared the lead in the Chrysler Classic at one point, but is still seeking his first PGA Tour victory.
1821552.xml.title: Corrections

1820457.xml.text: An article last Sunday about a monthly series of talks by Columbia University science professors at an Upper West Side restaurant incorrectly described two eighth graders in the audience. They were Sarah Friedhoff, a 13-year-old girl, and Miguel Alonso-Lubell, a 13-year-old boy -- not two boys.
1820457.xml.title: Corrections

1817159.xml.text: A picture with an article last Sunday about the sale of Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village in Manhattan by Metropolitan Life Insurance was published in error. It showed Frederic W. Ecker, who served as president and chief executive of MetLife beginning in 1953 -- not his father, Frederick H. Ecker, who was chairman and chief executive when the developments were built in the 1940s.
1817159.xml.title: Corrections

1819310.xml.text: A headline in Business Day on Saturday about a federal investigation that led to the indictment of a Michigan executive, Patrick J. Harrington, on charges of falsifying information on 76 small-business loans, referred incorrectly to the company under scrutiny. It is Business Loan Express, a unit of the Allied Capital Corporation -- not Allied Capital itself.
1819310.xml.title: Corrections

1819119.xml.text: A graphic about the growth of Pentecostalism that accompanied an article yesterday about a storefront church in Harlem referred imprecisely to the beliefs of evangelicals. Some evangelicals believe in the literal truth of the Bible; not all do.
1819119.xml.title: Corrections

1821826.xml.text: A front-page article last Saturday about complaints by some nonprofit groups of a class divide in philanthropy among Chinese-Americans misstated the given name of the executive director of the Ong Family Foundation, which makes annual grants to such groups, including the Chinese-American Planning Council, a social service agency. The executive director is Nelson Louis, not Norman. The article also misstated the association that Mr. Louis and Danny Ong Yee, the foundation's founding trustee, once had with the council. They are former staff members; they did not attend the council's child-care programs as children.
1821826.xml.title: Corrections

1821043.xml.text: An article on Friday about the Pentagon's new rules for military commissions to try prisoners held at Guantánamo, Cuba, on terrorism charges, misstated the reasons cited by the Supreme Court when it struck down the Bush administration's original plans for the commissions. And a correction in this space yesterday repeated the error. The court ruled last year in Hamdan v. Rumsfeld that the initial procedures established for the commissions were unauthorized by federal statute and violated international law. It did not rule that the commissions themselves were unconstitutional.
1821043.xml.title: Corrections

1817862.xml.text: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Jan. 1 about plans by the Walt Disney Company to introduce a revamped Web site at the Consumer Electronics Show referred incorrectly to the business relationship between Apple and Pixar Animation Studios. While Apple's chief executive, Steven P. Jobs, was once the majority shareholder in Pixar, Apple never owned the animation studio.
1817862.xml.title: Corrections

1822659.xml.text: A classical music entry in the Listings pages of Weekend on Jan. 19 misstated the history of the performance in New York of ''Il Signor Bruschino,'' by Rossini, which the Gotham Chamber Orchestra is performing through Saturday. The Gotham Chamber Orchestra's production is the first professional staging of the work in New York since 1933, not the first staging since then. (The error was repeated in a Week Ahead entry in Arts & Leisure on Jan. 21, in the Listings pages of Weekend on Friday and in a review of a performance on Saturday.)  Correction:  February 1, 2007, Thursday  A classical music entry in the Listings pages of Weekend on Jan. 19 misstated the history of the performance in New York of ''Il Signor Bruschino,'' by Rossini, which is being performed in New York through Saturday. The current production is the first professional staging of the work in New York since 1933, not the first staging since then. (The error was repeated in a Week Ahead entry in Arts & Leisure on Jan. 21, in the Listings pages of Weekend on Friday and in a review of a performance on Saturday.) A correction in this space on Tuesday misstated the name of the group that is currently presenting the work, at the Abrons Arts Center on the Lower East Side. It is the Gotham Chamber Opera, not Orchestra.
1822659.xml.title: Corrections

1822654.xml.text: An article on Jan. 12 about the awarding of the Medal of Honor to Cpl. Jason L. Dunham of Scio, N.Y., referred incorrectly to his military service. Corporal Dunham, who was killed in Iraq after throwing himself on a grenade to protect two men in his unit, was a marine, not a soldier. He is the first marine and the second service member -- not the second soldier -- to receive the Medal of Honor for service in the war in Iraq. The article also misstated the number of medals that have been awarded since World War II and misstated the timing of restrictions that tightened the criteria for the medal. There have been 380 medals awarded since then, not ''slightly more than 840.'' The requirements were tightened during the war, not after it.
1822654.xml.title: Corrections

1820946.xml.text: An obituary on Thursday aboutBob Zawoluk, a St. John's basketball star, misstated the number of points he scored in his record-setting game against St. Peter's in 1950. It was 65 points, not 56.
1820946.xml.title: Corrections

1821327.xml.text: A front-page article yesterday about events surrounding President Bush's State of the Union speech misquoted his opening remarks. He said, ''And tonight I have the high privilege and distinct honor of my own as the first president to begin the State of the Union Message with these words: 'Madam Speaker.' '' He did not say, ''Tonight, I have the high privilege and distinct honor to begin a speech with the words 'Madam Speaker.' ''
1821327.xml.title: Corrections

1821334.xml.text: An article yesterday about Senator Jim Webb of Virginia and his response, for the Democratic Party, to the State of Union address omitted part of a conversation he had with President Bush at a White House reception for new members of Congress in November. President Bush approached Mr. Webb, whose son is a marine serving in Iraq, and asked, ''How's your boy?'' Mr. Webb replied, ''I'd like to get them out of Iraq, Mr. President.'' Mr. Webb did not say at that point in the conversation, ''That's between me and my boy, Mr. President.'' Mr. Webb did not make that statement until after Mr. Bush had said of the Iraq comment: ''That's not what I asked you. How's your boy?''  The article also referred incorrectly to how Mr. Webb's speech dealt with Democrats' response to the president's Iraq strategy. The speech did not mention whether the party will go beyond a symbolic resolution denouncing Mr. Bush's plan to send more troops to Baghdad.
1821334.xml.title: Corrections

1822444.xml.text: A picture caption on the Square Feet pages of Business Day on Wednesday with an article about the bidding war for Equity Office Properties referred imprecisely to E.O.P.'s control of the Ferry Building in San Francisco. While E.O.P. and its partners have a long-term lease on the building, they have not acquired the property. The building is owned by the Port of San Francisco.
1822444.xml.title: Corrections

1816594.xml.text: An article on Sunday about some of the more captivating events in the New York region in 2006 referred incorrectly to a federal investigation of Jared Paul Stern, a former contributor to the Page Six section of The New York Post whom Ronald W. Burkle, the supermarket magnate, has accused of an extortion attempt. The investigation came to light when it was reported by The Post; it was not announced by federal authorities. In addition, allegations that Mr. Stern had been caught on video demanding a $100,000 payment, as well as monthly stipends, for keeping negative accounts of Mr. Burkle from the press were made by Mr. Burkle, not by federal authorities.
1816594.xml.title: Corrections

1822440.xml.text: An article on Thursday about a compromise bill that would ban smoking in most areas of Atlantic City casinos referred incorrectly in some copies to gambling establishments in Massachusetts. The state is considering allowing casinos, but has none yet.
1822440.xml.title: Corrections

1821328.xml.text: An article in Business Day yesterday about Yahoo's quarterly earnings misstated the reason given for the departure of the company's chief operating officer, Daniel L. Rosensweig, which was announced last month. He resigned; he was not fired.
1821328.xml.title: Corrections

1817659.xml.text: An article last Tuesday about possible divisions among Democrats in Congress misstated the number of Democratic freshmen in the House. It is 42, not 30. (Democrats took over 30 Republican-held seats and 12 seats that had been vacated by Democrats.)
1817659.xml.title: Corrections

1822830.xml.text: The front-page Your Money column on Saturday, about the possibility that people might be saving too much for retirement, misstated the parameters of a calculator from Fidelity Investments that helps consumers determine their future financial needs. Social Security payments are included -- not excluded -- in Fidelity's calculations.
1822830.xml.title: Corrections

1818696.xml.text: A credit last Sunday for a picture with an article about the art of writing lyrics misspelled a given name, provided by The Associated Press. The photo of Ira Gershwin was from the Ira and Leonore Gershwin Trusts -- not Lenore.
1818696.xml.title: Corrections

1819712.xml.text: An obituary last Thursday about Roberta Wohlstetter, a military and foreign policy analyst, misstated the surname of her mother and reversed the middle name and surname of her father. Her mother was Elsie Morgan, not Morris. Her father was Edmund Morris Morgan -- not Morgan Morris.
1819712.xml.title: Corrections

1821823.xml.text: A chart yesterday with an article about declining union membership gave outdated information on the states with the highest and lowest membership in 2006. The top states were Hawaii (24.7%), New York (24.4%), Alaska (22.2%), New Jersey (20.1%) and Washington (19.8%); the bottom states were Texas (4.9%), Georgia (4.4%), Virginia (4.0%), and North and South Carolina (both with 3.3%). The chart listed the 2005 rankings. (As the article noted correctly, the national average is 12 percent, based on 2006 figures.)
1821823.xml.title: Corrections

1821827.xml.text: An article on Jan. 12 about Staten Island Chuck, a groundhog being prepared for his first Groundhog Day duty by commuting home with his trainer on weekends, included an outdated reference to the train system that Chuck travels on. Since 1994, it has been called the Staten Island Railway, not Staten Island Rapid Transit.
1821827.xml.title: Corrections

1816163.xml.text: An art review in Weekend on Dec. 15 about Queens International 2006, at the Queens Museum of Art, misspelled the given name of the artist whose embroidered panels explore female sexuality. She is Blanka Amezcua, not Blanca.
1816163.xml.title: Corrections

1817661.xml.text: A front-page article last Tuesday about Wal-Mart's struggle to market a long-lasting, energy-saving light bulb known as a compact fluorescent lamp misstated the time period in which the retailer sold 40 million of the bulbs compared with about 350 million incandescent bulbs. It was from August 2005 to August 2006 -- not in 2005.
1817661.xml.title: Corrections

1820107.xml.text: A sports article on Thursday about the sale of naming rights for the Nets' planned home in Brooklyn referred imprecisely to the arena's anticipated cost. Although the price will indeed exceed $550 million, the latest cost projection has raised it to about $637 million. The article also referred incompletely to a park planned atop the arena. It will be a private open space for the complex; it will not be a public park.
1820107.xml.title: Corrections

1819949.xml.text: An article on Jan. 4 about heart-valve problems linked to two drugs for Parkinson's disease misstated the year that one of them, Permax, added a black-box warning label, the strongest warning required by the Food and Drug Administration. It was 2006, not 2003.
1819949.xml.title: Corrections

1820947.xml.text: An obituary on Saturday about Denny Doherty, a founding member of the folk-pop band the Mamas and the Papas, misstated the name of the television network that later produced his popular television show, ''Theodore Tugboat.'' It is the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, not the Canadian Broadcasting Company.
1820947.xml.title: Corrections

1818495.xml.text: A chart on Jan. 2 with the continuation of a front-page article about Wal-Mart's struggle to market an energy-saving light bulb known as a compact fluorescent lamp referred incompletely to mercury emissions in comparing two light bulbs. The emissions -- 2.4 milligrams from the fluorescent lamp and 10 milligrams for an incandescent bulb -- occur at a coal-powered plant generating the electricity needed for the bulbs. The bulbs themselves do not emit mercury.
1818495.xml.title: Corrections

1819307.xml.text: An article in The Arts on Wednesday about the writer Vikram Chandra misidentified the site of his home. While he teaches at the University of California, Berkeley, he lives in Oakland, Calif., not Berkeley.
1819307.xml.title: Corrections

1822836.xml.text: An article in The Arts on Jan. 13 about the writer Harold L. Humes misstated the time frame during which he served as campaign manager for Norman Mailer. He was the manager for Mr. Mailer's aborted campaign for mayor of New York in the early 1960s, not in 1969. (Joe Flaherty was the manager of the campaign in that year.)
1822836.xml.title: Corrections

1818348.xml.text: An article in Business Day yesterday about the media company E.W. Scripps, and the possible sale of some of its newspapers, misattributed a quotation explaining the reason for the strategy. It was the chief financial officer Joseph G. NeCastro -- not the chief executive Kenneth W. Lowe -- who said: ''Clearly the most advantageous route is to separate the newspaper business in some fashion.''
1818348.xml.title: Corrections

1819701.xml.text: An article on Jan. 4 about Delores Pryce, a Queens woman whose youngest daughter has health problems and who received help from The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund to help pay an electricity bill, referred incorrectly to New Alternatives for Children, a program that helps families with medically fragile children. (The error was repeated in an article on Jan. 5 about Dorcas Acheampong, a Bronx woman who received help from the fund to help pay her rent.) Although it is a member agency of the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, it is not run by the federation.
1819701.xml.title: Corrections

1816598.xml.text: An article yesterday about a guilty plea by Army Specialist Juston R. Graber to a reduced charge of mercy killing in connection with the deaths of three Iraqi men misstated the original charge against him and the maximum punishment three other soldiers could receive if convicted. Specialist Graber was charged with noncapital murder, not capital murder. The three other soldiers scheduled for courts-martial face life in prison -- not the death penalty -- if convicted.
1816598.xml.title: Corrections

1821834.xml.text: An article on Wednesday about a pointed exchange between CNN and Fox News over a Web site report that said Senator Barack Obama had attended an Islamic school or madrassa in Indonesia as a child referred imprecisely to madrassas. While some teach a radical version of Islam, most historically have not. (Mr. Obama's office has said the report is untrue.)
1821834.xml.title: Corrections

1819122.xml.text: A report in the On Baseball column on Jan. 7 about Gil Meche and Ron Guidry, two pitchers from different eras but the same hometown, Lafayette, La., misstated the team that signed Meche to a five-year, $55 million contract this off-season. It is the Kansas City Royals, not the Seattle Mariners.
1819122.xml.title: Corrections

1816764.xml.text: The Religion Journal last Saturday, about the complexities of tithing, misstated the name of a company where Tom Norwood, a Presbyterian minister, advises churches on how to increase giving by their congregants. It is Capstone Advancement Partners, not Capstone Investment Partners.
1816764.xml.title: Corrections

1818347.xml.text: An article in Business Day yesterday about a lawsuit filed by a pension fund over the proposed merger between Caremark RX and CVS misstated the amount of exit pay that Caremark's chief executive, Edwin M. Crawford, would receive if a rival bid was accepted. If Express Scripts succeeds in its rival bid, Mr. Crawford would receive $57.6 million to $62.4 million, not an estimated $48 million.
1818347.xml.title: Corrections

1817266.xml.text: A column last Sunday on a day laborer who was arrested in Danbury misspelled the given name of one of several Yale Law School students who is representing him. She is Stacie Jonas, not Staci.
1817266.xml.title: Corrections

1816350.xml.text: The On Education column yesterday, about A Better Chance, a nonprofit group that helps minority children apply to private day and boarding high schools, misstated the surname of the president of the group and omitted her middle initial. She is Sandra E. Timmons, not Simmons.
1816350.xml.title: Corrections

1819303.xml.text: A picture caption on Friday about the English soccer star David Beckham, who has a five-year agreement to play for the Los Angeles Galaxy of Major League Soccer, misstated his role in a score in a 2002 World Cup game against Sweden. His corner kick set up a goal; he did not score a goal.
1819303.xml.title: Corrections

1816833.xml.text: The ''Living In'' article last Sunday, on the Stuyvesant Square neighborhood, referred incorrectly to the Manhattan Comprehensive Night and Day High School. It is public, not private. The article also misstated the school's hours. It is open 9 a.m. to 11 p.m. on Monday through Thursday, 9 a.m. to 8 p.m. on Friday and 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. on Sunday.
1816833.xml.title: Corrections

1819948.xml.text: An article on Monday about the crime and discontent that has accompanied prosperity for some in the Chinese city of Guangzhou referred incorrectly to the city's economic development. It has reached $7,800 per capita gross domestic product -- not per capita income.
1819948.xml.title: Corrections

1821336.xml.text: An article on Jan. 14 about efforts by the Carnegie, Ford and Rockefeller Foundations to improve their operations referred incorrectly to the Spike Lee documentary on New Orleans, ''When the Levees Broke,'' which was underwritten by the Rockefeller Foundation. The documentary itself, in DVD form, is the basis of a curriculum on poverty developed by Teachers College at Columbia. It is not being used to create 20-to-30 minute DVDs for the curriculum.
1821336.xml.title: Corrections

1817655.xml.text: A Man in the News article on Saturday about Zalmay Khalilzad, President Bush's choice to be ambassador to the United Nations, misidentified the first American ambassador to Afghanistan after the fall of the Taliban. It was Robert P. Finn -- not Mr. Khalilzad, who succeeded Mr. Finn in the fall of 2003.
1817655.xml.title: Corrections

1821543.xml.text: An article yesterday about Senator John Kerry's announcement that he would not seek the Democratic nomination for president in 2008 incorrectly described what he called ''a botched joke'' he told before the November midterm elections. In telling the joke, which was assailed as an attack on American troops fighting in Iraq, Mr. Kerry not only dropped a word from his prepared remarks, but he also rephrased his opening sentence extensively and omitted a reference to President Bush. Mr. Kerry's aides said that the prepared text read: ''Do you know where you end up if you don't study, if you aren't smart, if you're intellectually lazy? You end up getting us stuck in a war in Iraq. Just ask President Bush.'' What he actually said: ''You know, education, if you make the most of it, you study hard, you do your homework and you make an effort to be smart, you can do well. If you don't, you get stuck in Iraq.''
1821543.xml.title: Corrections

1819920.xml.text: An article last Friday about observing butterflies in the Lower Rio Grande Valley misstated the trees that are hung with Spanish moss there. Many indigenous trees, including species of elm and ash, have Spanish moss there, but oaks are not among them.
1819920.xml.title: Corrections

1820975.xml.text: An article in Business Day on Saturday, about efforts by the drug maker Bristol-Myers Squibb to recover from a competitive challenge to its best-selling blood thinner, Plavix, misstated the board's position on potential merger or takeover deals involving the company. While Bristol-Myers executives have said repeatedly that they would be open to considering such deals, the board has not actively pursued a merger or sale.
1820975.xml.title: Corrections

1818343.xml.text: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about possible campaign headquarters for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton misidentified one of the places she has considered home. It is Washington, D.C., not Washington State.
1818343.xml.title: Corrections

1820974.xml.text: A news analysis article on Sunday about Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's presidential prospects misstated the results of a recent Washington Post/ABC News poll and erroneously attributed the incorrect number to a statement by her campaign. Mrs. Clinton led Senator Barack Obama in the preference poll of likely Democratic primary voters by 41 percent to 17 percent; she did not hold a 41 percentage point lead over Mr. Obama. The campaign's statement correctly reflected the polling data; it did not contain the incorrect percentage.
1820974.xml.title: Corrections

1817861.xml.text: A front-page article on Dec. 19, about the financial problems that health plans for retired government workers are causing in some cities, misstated the amount that New York City intends to set aside in a trust fund to pay for its retired workers' health care. It is $2 billion, which is to be paid over fiscal years 2006 and 2007 -- not $2.2 billion, which is the city's contribution to the trust fund in fiscal 2006 as well as its outlay for retiree health care in the same year.
1817861.xml.title: Corrections

1818082.xml.text: A picture caption in Business Day on Monday with an article about cellphones and other small devices that take on desktop computers' functions referred incorrectly to four officials from Oqo, which makes a pocket-sized computer. While the four pictured are executives, only three were among its founders. Bob Rosin, second from right, is the senior vice president for marketing and alliances and joined the company later.
1818082.xml.title: Corrections

1820110.xml.text: A film column on Jan. 10 about the New York Jewish Film Festival misidentified the voice-over featured in the animated short ''Chronicles of a Professional Eulogist.'' While the film is based on interviews with a rabbi who is the stepfather of the writer's wife, the voice is that of Jonathan Milder, not the rabbi.
1820110.xml.title: Corrections

1817267.xml.text: A chart with an article last Sunday about the changing demographics of the suburbs contained incorrect percentages for levels of education reported by the census in 2000 and 2005. In 2005, the proportion of the population over 25 with some college was 22.6 percent, not 28.1 percent. In 2000, the proportions in all groups were slightly higher than those reported: The proportion with less than a high school degree was 15.8 percent; the proportion with a high school degree was 27.7 percent; with some college, 23.7 percent; with a college degree, 19.3 percent; with a master's degree, 9.1 percent; with a professional degree, 4.3 percent.
1817267.xml.title: Corrections

1820941.xml.text: A report in the Metro Briefing column on Jan. 5 about appointments by Gov. Eliot Spitzer of New York misspelled the given name of the deputy commissioner of the Office of Health Insurance Programs, a new position. (The error was repeated on Thursday in an article about the expected appointment of a new state health commissioner.) She is Deborah Bachrach, not Debra.
1820941.xml.title: Corrections

1820098.xml.text: A picture caption with a front-page article on Jan. 9 about the naming of Fred F. Fielding as the chief White House lawyer misspelled the surname of a woman, whose husband was killed in the Sept. 11 attacks, who spoke to Mr. Fielding at a meeting of the Sept. 11 commission when he was on that panel. She is Beverly Eckert, not Ecket.
1820098.xml.title: Corrections

1819497.xml.text: An article on Sunday about a gun battle on Jan. 3 between the police and Islamic extremists in Tunisia misstated the name of a militant Islamic political party that has risen in popularity as part of a religious resurgence across North Africa. The party, based in Egypt, is the Muslim Brotherhood, not Islamic Brotherhood.
1819497.xml.title: Corrections

1819504.xml.text: An article in the Itineraries pages of Business Day yesterday about finding places to eat while traveling for business misstated the name of a Web site that offers restaurant information. It is www.fodors.com, not www.fodor.com.
1819504.xml.title: Corrections

1821083.xml.text: An obituary on Jan. 12 about the producer and writer Steve Krantz misspelled the surname of his surviving sister. She is Sunny Onish, not Ornish.
1821083.xml.title: Corrections

1816349.xml.text: An article on Monday about the handling of the video of Saddam Hussein's execution by television networks and Web sites referred imprecisely to the site littlegreenfootballs.com. It posted a link to the video, not the video itself.
1816349.xml.title: Corrections

1817660.xml.text: A brief report on Thursday about Andrea Stewart-Cousins, a freshman New York State senator, in an article about the opening session of the State Legislature, misstated the number of new senators taking office and referred imprecisely to the historical significance of Ms. Stewart-Cousins' election. Counting Ms. Stewart-Cousins, there are seven new senators; she is not the only one. She is one of a few candidates in recent years to have won by defeating an incumbent; more commonly, newcomers win by running for open seats.
1817660.xml.title: Corrections

1819951.xml.text: A chart on Tuesday with the continuation of a front-page article about the slowdown in the condominium market mislabeled the top line of the scale showing the number of condos for sale. It is 25,000, not 30,000. A corrected graphic can be found at nytimes.com/2007/01/16/realestate/16rentals.html.
1819951.xml.title: Corrections

1819301.xml.text: An article in Business Day on Jan. 1 about the increase in subscribers for Sirius Satellite Radio and its rival, XM Satellite Radio, misstated one news channel that is offered by both companies. It is CNBC, not MSNBC.
1819301.xml.title: Corrections

1819126.xml.text: An obituary on Wednesday about Iwao Takamoto, the artist who created Scooby-Doo and other cartoon characters, in some copies misstated the day that he died. It was Monday, not last Tuesday.
1819126.xml.title: Corrections

1819703.xml.text: An article on Sunday about a record set in 2006 for the amount of borrowed money the New York Legislature and Gov. George E. Pataki committed to pet projects included an erroneous reference from David Catalfamo, a spokesman for Mr. Pataki, to a museum that Mr. Catalfamo defended as a worthwhile investment. It is the Natural History Museum of the Adirondacks in Tupper Lake -- not the Adirondack Museum, which is in Blue Mountain Lake.
1819703.xml.title: Corrections

1819306.xml.text: A report in the ''Arts, Briefly'' column on Friday about the decision by the boards of Carnegie Hall and City Center to form a partnership for performances referred incorrectly to the plan. Each institution will maintain its own board; a partnership board will not be formed.
1819306.xml.title: Corrections

1818083.xml.text: Because of an editing error, an article in Weekend on Friday about a walk in the East Village with Robert Stone, who has a new memoir about the 1960s, ''Prime Green,'' misstated the history of Andy Warhol's connection with the Polski Dom, or Polish Home, on St. Marks Place. The nightclub Warhol opened there, in 1966, was called Dom, not the Electric Circus. (The Electric Circus, not run by Warhol, opened at the site in 1967.)  A map with the article omitted identification of one street and misidentified two others. The unidentified street north of St. Marks Place is East Ninth Street; the two streets north of that are East 10th and East 11th -- not East Ninth and East 10th.  The map also included an imprecise translation of the German name Deutsche-Amerikanische Schützen Gesellschaft, engraved on the building at 12 St. Marks Place, built in 1885. The ''German-American Shooting Club'' is a more precise translation and description of the organization's function in the community than ''German-American Shooting School.''
1818083.xml.title: Corrections

1819706.xml.text: An article in Business Day on Monday about a dispute between Wendy P. McCaw, the owner of The Santa Barbara News-Press in California and the newsroom staff misspelled the name of the city where Don Murphy, the former manager editor of the paper, has taken a job. It is San Luis Obispo, not San Louis Obispo. The credit for a picture of Ms. McCaw misstated the given name of the photographer. He is Paul Wellman, not Paula.
1819706.xml.title: Corrections

1816161.xml.text: An art review in Weekend on Friday about four shows at the P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center in Queens misstated the name of the artist who has a large embroidered silk screen in the ''Gold Standard'' show. He is Kent Henricksen, not Kurt Hendrickson.  The review also misidentified the country in which workers at a gold mine are shown in a short video by Alfredo Jaar called ''Introduction to a Distant World.'' It is Brazil, not South Africa.  It also misstated the year that Neville Wakefield, who put together the ''Defamation of Character'' show, became a curatorial adviser at P.S. 1. It was at the beginning of 2006, not the beginning of 2005.
1816161.xml.title: Corrections

1820103.xml.text: An article in Business Day on Dec. 29 about concessions that investors in oil and gas fields have given the Russia government misspelled the name of one gas field involved. (The error also appeared in articles last year on Nov. 8, Oct. 11, Sept. 23 and March 22.) It is Kovykta, not Kovytka.
1820103.xml.title: Corrections

1816602.xml.text: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about an investigation of Qualcomm by the antitrust authorities in South Korea misspelled the given name of the president of Nextreaming, which has accused Qualcomm of undermining fair competition. It is Lim Il-taek, not Lim Il-tiek.
1816602.xml.title: Corrections

1818498.xml.text: A television review on Jan. 2 about ''Dirt,'' on FX, referred incorrectly to the channel. It is a basic cable channel, not a premium one.
1818498.xml.title: Corrections

1816763.xml.text: A picture caption in Business Day yesterday about a decision by the McCormick Tribune Foundation, a large shareholder in the Tribune Company, to hire the Blackstone Group as an adviser while the Tribune is up for sale, misstated the role of the company's chief executive, Dennis FitzSimons, in the sales process. Mr. FitzSimons, who is also chairman of the foundation's board, has recused himself from issues regarding the sale; he is not a member of the special committee dealing with the Blackstone Group.
1816763.xml.title: Corrections

1821074.xml.text: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Sunday about Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's presidential candidacy misstated the name of the university whose president, former Senator Bob Kerrey, commented on campaign donors. It is the New School, not the New School University.
1821074.xml.title: Corrections

1821824.xml.text: An article by The Associated Press last Saturday about a fatal stabbing at the Lincoln-Sudbury Regional High School in Massachusetts misstated the school's location. It is in Sudbury, not Framingham.
1821824.xml.title: Corrections

1816773.xml.text: A report in the ''Arts, Briefly'' column last Saturday about criticism of officials at the J. Paul Getty Museum by the former antiquities curator referred imprecisely to the origin of two artifacts that the museum agreed to hand over to Greece last month. Although the Greek government contends they were looted from Greek soil, and the Getty says they should rightfully be returned, there has been no independent finding that the objects were illegally excavated.
1816773.xml.title: Corrections

1817669.xml.text: An article in The Arts on Thursday about the formation of a new dance company by the choreographer Christopher Wheeldon misstated the name of one of the companies that asked him in the past to choreograph for it. It is the Pennsylvania Ballet (based in Philadelphia), not the Philadelphia Ballet.
1817669.xml.title: Corrections

1816357.xml.text: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about the debate over free will misstated the location of Elizabethtown College, where Michael Silberstein, who commented on free will and popular culture, is a science philosopher. It is in Pennsylvania, not Maryland.
1816357.xml.title: Corrections

1819500.xml.text: An article on Monday about Orthodox Jews from Monsey, N.Y., who belong to Neturei Karta, an anti-Zionist group, and who traveled to Iran last month for a conference questioning the Holocaust, referred incorrectly to the locations where the group has members. They are in the United States, the United Kingdom and Canada, among other places, but not in the Jewish settlements of the West Bank.
1819500.xml.title: Corrections

1819496.xml.text: A headline and an entry in the News Summary on Monday about Middle East peace efforts by Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice misstated the location where she held talks with Mahmoud Abbas, president of the Palestinian Authority. It was in the West Bank city of Ramallah, not in Pakistan.
1819496.xml.title: Corrections

1816353.xml.text: An entry in the Transactions column in the Square Feet pages of Business Day yesterday about a recent lease at 111 John Street, Manhattan, carried incorrect information from a broker about the new tenant. It is Habitat for Humanity-New York City, not Habitat for Humanity International. The entry also listed the rent incorrectly. It is $25 per square foot, not $27.
1816353.xml.title: Corrections

1822107.xml.text: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about furniture stores in Dumbo, Brooklyn, misstated the context of a quotation by Robert Siewert, the manager at Wonk, one of the stores. When Mr. Siewert said, ''This building, before they started getting kicked out, was mostly artist studios,'' he was referring to a building at 68 Jay Street, where his store is located -- not to the nearby J Condominiums.
1822107.xml.title: Corrections

1820106.xml.text: The Advertising column in Business Day on Thursday, about the successful online ad campaign for LowerMyBills.com, misspelled the given name of a blogger who commented on the ads. He is Rogers Cadenhead, not Roger.
1820106.xml.title: Corrections

1818489.xml.text: A report by Reuters in the World Briefing column yesterday about the projected imbalance in population numbers between men and women in China because of the one-child policy and a cultural preference for sons misstated the anticipated shift in the population. The state news media predicted that by 2020 the country would have 30 million more men than women, not 300 million more.
1818489.xml.title: Corrections

1819299.xml.text: An article on Thursday about opposition to a high-explosive test in the Nevada desert because of fears it would propel radioactive particles in the soil from nuclear weapons tests misstated the number of nuclear tests there from 1951 to 1992. It is 928, not 100. The article also misidentified the unit of measure for radiation exposure. It is the millirem, not milliliter.
1819299.xml.title: Corrections

1817665.xml.text: A sports article on Saturday about the former quarterback Koy Detmer, who was signed by the Philadelphia Eagles to be the holder on kicks in the playoffs, misidentified the special-teams coach. He is John Harbaugh, not Jim Harbaugh. (The Harbaughs are brothers. Jim was recently hired as head coach at Stanford University.)
1817665.xml.title: Corrections

1819950.xml.text: An article on Wednesday about a 1906 Maxfield Parrish painting of Old King Cole, which was removed from the St. Regis Hotel in Manhattan for its first extensive cleaning since the 1950s, misidentified the man who commissioned it and whose face is believed to have been the model for the king's. He is John Jacob Astor IV -- not John Jacob Astor, his great-grandfather.
1819950.xml.title: Corrections

1816769.xml.text: An article last Saturday about memorials in Washington, D.C., that are dedicated to the history of other countries misstated the location of a statue to Tomas Masaryk, the first president of Czechoslovakia. It is at the intersection of 22nd Street, Massachusetts Avenue and Q Street -- not in front of the World Bank on H Street.
1816769.xml.title: Corrections

1822663.xml.text: An obituary on Jan. 15 about Alice Coltrane, the widow and piano accompanist of the jazz saxophonist John Coltrane, referred incompletely to the musician Terry Gibbs, with whom she played early in her career. Although he plays the drums, he is best known as a vibraphonist.
1822663.xml.title: Corrections

1821079.xml.text: An article in The Arts last Wednesday about NBC's plans to extend the ''Today'' program to a fourth hour attributed an erroneous distinction to the show. ''Nightwatch'' on CBS, which had its premiere in 1982, ran for four hours on weekdays. ''Today'' will not be the first such weekday program of that length on major broadcast networks.
1821079.xml.title: Corrections

1822450.xml.text: An obituary on Dec. 1 about Rose Mattus, who with her husband created Häagen-Dazs Ice Cream, misidentified the company that owns the brand. It is General Mills, not Nestlé. (General Mills has licensed Nestlé to sell some of its brands in the United States and Canada.)
1822450.xml.title: Corrections

1816593.xml.text: An article about San Antonio last Friday included outdated information about a barbecue stand in the city. The Pig Stand at 801 South Presa Street is no longer in business. The article also referred incorrectly to the San Antonio River along the River Walk. The bulk of the River Walk follows the natural flow of the river, not a diverted section.
1816593.xml.title: Corrections

1821549.xml.text: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about a chip deal between Sun Microsystems and Intel and its effect on an Intel rival, Advanced Micro Devices, rendered incorrectly a quotation from a research note by an analyst with Stifel Nicolaus, Cody Acree. He wrote, ''Now A.M.D. has missed the last two quarters'' -- not that ''Intel'' has missed the last two quarters.
1821549.xml.title: Corrections

1822838.xml.text: An obituary on Jan. 14 about A. I. Bezzerides, who wrote several novels that were adapted for films, omitted part of the title of one film and misidentified its director. The title is ''On Dangerous Ground,'' not ''Dangerous Ground,'' and the director was Nicholas Ray, not James Dassin.
1822838.xml.title: Corrections

1818345.xml.text: The Advertising column in Business Day yesterday, about digital technology that rotates advertiser images on highway billboards, carried incorrect estimates from the Outdoor Advertising Association of America on the number of billboards that are expected to be converted to digital in the next 10 years. It is 4,000, not 90,000.
1818345.xml.title: Corrections

1820456.xml.text: An article last Sunday about a surge in attendance at the American Museum of Natural History since the release of the film ''Night at the Museum'' referred incorrectly to an artifact at the museum. The museum has a cast of bones from the Peking man fossils -- not an actual skull of a Peking man. Most of the Peking man fossils were lost during World War II.
1820456.xml.title: Corrections

1819955.xml.text: Movie details with a film review of ''Arthur and the Invisibles'' in Weekend last Friday included an erroneous running time provided by the distributor and referred incorrectly to the movie's rating. The film is 94 minutes, not 102, and it is rated PG; it is not unrated.
1819955.xml.title: Corrections

1818319.xml.text: A picture caption with an article last Friday about the writer Maya Angelou's part-time home in New York misstated the number of its rooms. It has 12 rooms -- not 18, which is the number of rooms in her home in Winston-Salem, N.C.
1818319.xml.title: Corrections

1818491.xml.text: A news analysis article yesterday about a bill on stem cell research passed by the House misstated one of its provisions. The measure would allow scientists receiving federal funds to use embryonic stem cells from surplus embryos generated in fertility clinics, after the cell lines had been derived by others using nonfederal funds. The federally supported scientists would not derive the cell lines themselves.
1818491.xml.title: Corrections

1818353.xml.text: An article on Sunday about separatist rebel attacks in the northeast Indian state of Assam misstated its precise location. Assam borders several other Indian states and the kingdom of Bhutan; it does not border Myanmar.
1818353.xml.title: Corrections

1816771.xml.text: A front-page article on Thursday about the side effects of the psychiatric drug Zyprexa misstated the name of a older drug tested against Zyprexa in a federally sponsored clinical trial. It was perphenazine (also called Trilafon), not Stelazine.
1816771.xml.title: Corrections

1817656.xml.text: An article on Sunday about marines charged in the killing of 24 Iraqis in the village of Haditha in November 2005 misidentified the Pennyslvania hometown of one marine because of information provided by his lawyer. The marine, Lance Cpl. Justin Sharratt, is from Canonsburg, not Carbondale. (The error also appeared in articles on Dec. 6 and Dec. 22.)
1817656.xml.title: Corrections

1822829.xml.text: A front-page article on Friday about efforts by public colleges to attract minority students misstated the name of the organization headed by Roger Clegg that opposes racial preferences. It is the Center for Equal Opportunity, not the Council for Equal Opportunity.
1822829.xml.title: Corrections

1818078.xml.text: An article on Tuesday about a controversy over the arrest of a political activist, Kenneth Krayeske, during the inaugural parade of Gov. M.
