Jodi Rell of Connecticut, misstated his age and misstated the surname of his lawyer. Mr. Krayeske is 34, not 33, and his lawyer is Norman A. Pattis, not Potts.
1818078.xml.title: Corrections

1818080.xml.text: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about the corporate takeover battle emerging in Asia for Hutchinson Essar, the telecommunications company, misstated its revenue in American dollars in some copies for the four quarters ended in June 2006. It was $1.58 billion -- not $12.38 billion, which is the amount of revenue in Hong Kong dollars.
1818080.xml.title: Corrections

1816595.xml.text: A front-page article yesterday about wiretapped conversations in the case against Jose Padilla, who is accused of plotting a ''dirty bomb'' attack, omitted two lines at the continuation in some copies. The sentence should have read: ''In the four and a half years since then, as the government tested the limits of its power to deal with terrorism outside the traditional law enforcement system, Mr. Padilla is the only accused terrorist to have gone from enemy combatant to criminal defendant.''
1816595.xml.title: Corrections

1821946.xml.text: The credits on Jan. 14 for two pictures with an article about the new Olympic Sculpture Park in Seattle were reversed. A photograph of the park at night was by Benjamin Benschneider, and a photograph of Alexander Calder's ''Eagle'' was by Paul Macapia.
1821946.xml.title: Corrections

1816160.xml.text: A sports article on Monday about the Knicks' 90-80 loss to the Clippers in Los Angeles misidentified the team that drafted guard Nate Robinson in 2005. It was the Phoenix Suns, who selected him at the Knicks' request, then traded him and Quentin Richardson to the Knicks for Kurt Thomas the same day; the Knicks did not draft Robinson.
1816160.xml.title: Corrections

1816354.xml.text: An article in The Arts on Tuesday about the most popular movies of 2006 and others that did not do as well at the box office referred incorrectly to two languages spoken in ''Babel,'' one of the films with subtitles that did not draw big crowds. They are Spanish and Berber, not ''Mexican'' and ''Moroccan.''
1816354.xml.title: Corrections

1818084.xml.text: An obituary on Jan. 3 about Teddy Kollek, the former mayor of Jerusalem, incorrectly rendered his birth name. He was Theodor Kollek, not Theodor Herzl Kollek. (Although he was named after Theodor Herzl, the founder of modern Zionism, he was not given a middle name, according to the Jerusalem Foundation, which he founded.)
1818084.xml.title: Corrections

1817664.xml.text: A report in the Fifth Down football roundup on Thursday about the American Football Conference's dominance over the National Football Conference during the regular season misstated the N.F.C. playoff team that had the best record (3-1) against A.F.C. teams. It is the Dallas Cowboys -- not the Giants, who were 1-3.
1817664.xml.title: Corrections

1820943.xml.text: An article on the Street Scene page of Business Day on Friday about Richard C. Breeden, the former top securities regulator who is started a hedge fund aimed at troubled companies, misstated his former position at the accounting firm Coopers & Lybrand. He was a co-chairman of the firm's international business; he did not run the firm.
1820943.xml.title: Corrections

1817663.xml.text: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about announcements by Sony and Microsoft regarding sales of their latest game consoles carried an incorrect dateline. The reporter was in San Francisco -- not Las Vegas, where the announcements were made at the Consumer Electronics Show.
1817663.xml.title: Corrections

1822449.xml.text: An entry in the Spare Times for Children listing in Weekend on Jan. 19, about the musical ''A Shelter in Our Car,'' at the Queensborough Performing Arts Center, misstated the name of the lead character. (The error was repeated on Friday.) She is Zettie, not Hettie.
1822449.xml.title: Corrections

1818930.xml.text: A photograph with an Inside summary on the front page of last Sunday's section, about a couple looking for a rental near a park where they could walk their dog, carried an erroneous credit. The photographer was Suzanne DeChillo of The New York Times -- not Marko Georgiev, a freelancer.
1818930.xml.title: Corrections

1822828.xml.text: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about the future of relations between Turkey and Armenia following the funeral for Hrant Dink, a Turkish-Armenian newspaper editor killed in Istanbul on Jan. 19, misidentified the issue between the two countries that Turkey has said should be examined by a governmental history commission. It is the 1915 Armenian genocide -- not the political status of Nagorno-Karabakh, a region that Armenia claims but that Turkey recognizes as part of Azerbaijan.
1822828.xml.title: Corrections

1819953.xml.text: A sports article on Wednesday about a positive drug test by Barry Bonds misstated the number of random drug tests allowed under an agreement between Major League Baseball and the players association. In addition to testing players on each 40-man roster, the agreement provides for 600 random tests, not 580.
1819953.xml.title: Corrections

1818697.xml.text: A Theater entry last Sunday in the Week Ahead report misstated the company presenting ''The Merchant of Venice'' and ''The Jew of Malta'' in repertory. It is Theater for a New Audience, not Theater for a New City.
1818697.xml.title: Corrections

1821545.xml.text: An article on Aug. 31 about a decision by the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York to give some priests accused of child sexual abuse the choice of leaving the priesthood or moving to supervised housing in Westchester County -- an option that was later canceled -- misstated the jurisdiction of the archdiocese. It covers Manhattan, Staten Island and the Bronx in New York City, and seven other downstate counties -- not all of New York City and five other downstate counties. The error was discovered recently by a reporter reviewing The Times's archives.
1821545.xml.title: Corrections

1817865.xml.text: The headline for a film review in Weekend on Friday about ''Freedom Writers'' misidentified the California city in which the movie is set. It is Long Beach, not Los Angeles.  The listing of credits omitted a producer. Danny DeVito was a producer, along with Stacey Sher and Michael Shamberg.
1817865.xml.title: Corrections

1821829.xml.text: An article on Wednesday about the death of a shipyard worker at the Brooklyn Navy Yard misstated the given name of a spokesman for the federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration who said the accident was being investigated. He is John Chavez, not Juan.
1821829.xml.title: Corrections

1816770.xml.text: An article and picture caption on Dec. 27 about David A. Paterson, the incoming lieutenant governor of New York, and his father, Basil A. Paterson, the Democratic nominee for lieutenant governor in 1970, referred incorrectly to the senior Mr. Paterson. He was the second black politician nominated for statewide office in New York, not the first. (Edward R. Dudley, nominated for attorney general at the Democratic State Convention in 1962, holds that distinction.)
1816770.xml.title: Corrections

1820944.xml.text: The Link by Link column in Business Day on Jan. 15 about a court hearing on an injunction over access to documents from Eli Lilly, the pharmaceutical giant, on its antipsychotic drug, Zyprexa, misstated the title of George H. Freeman, a lawyer for The New York Times, who discussed the newspaper's approach to disseminating information contained in the documents. He is an assistant general counsel, not general counsel. (Kenneth A. Richieri is the general counsel.)
1820944.xml.title: Corrections

1816600.xml.text: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about layoffs at The Philadelphia Inquirer referred incorrectly to the newspaper's bureaus during the 1980s. The paper had a total of about 15 national and foreign bureaus; it did not have 15 foreign bureaus
1816600.xml.title: Corrections

1816603.xml.text: An article in Business Day yesterday about a proposed high-definition videodisc that will play on rival technologies referred incorrectly to one capability of the Blu-ray players, a rival to the HD-DVD technology. Blu-Ray players do, in fact, play standard DVDs, as do HD-DVD players. One difference is that some new HD-DVD discs are sold in a combination format that will also play on standard DVD players, while Blu-Ray discs currently do not have this feature.
1816603.xml.title: Corrections

1821080.xml.text: A Classical Music entry on Sunday in the Week Ahead report in Arts & Leisure incorrectly described ''Decasia,'' being performed Thursday through Saturday at Angel Orensanz Center for the Arts. The concert consists of a score by Michael Gordon and a film by Bill Morrison, not a video. The entry also omitted information about advance tickets. They are available only through ticketmania.com, not at the center.
1821080.xml.title: Corrections

1819505.xml.text: An article in The Arts on Saturday about an exhibition in Washington focusing on design inspired by Shakespeare's Globe Theater omitted a passage. It should have read: ''And the theater's basic design elements, such as they are known, have inspired loose architectural interpretations that range from the polygonal Festival Theater in Stratford, Ontario, to a Globe made entirely of ice hundreds of miles above the Arctic Circle in Sweden. The continuing fascination with Shakespeare's theater and the myriad efforts to replicate its spirit -- and, in many cases, its actual form -- is the subject of 'Reinventing the Globe: A Shakespearean Theater for the 21st Century,' an exhibition that opens on Saturday at the National Building Museum here as part of the city's six-month Shakespeare in Washington festival.''
1819505.xml.title: Corrections

1821337.xml.text: An article by Dow Jones/Associated Press in Business Day last Thursday about a decision by the Financial Accounting Standards Board not to delay a rule that requires companies to take a more stringent approach to reporting tax positions misstated the name of the organization that had requested the postponement. It is Tax Executives Institute, not Tax Executives International.
1821337.xml.title: Corrections

1821546.xml.text: Two picture captions on Sunday with an article about the transformation of East Harlem from a Puerto Rican enclave to a more heterogeneous neighborhood misidentified the location of buildings being renovated or constructed. They are on 117th Street, not 116th.
1821546.xml.title: Corrections

1822447.xml.text: The Critic's Choice column on Tuesday, about new DVDs, referred imprecisely to the title of Sergio Leone's pioneering spaghetti western, which was modeled on Akira Kurosawa's ''Yojimbo.'' The Leone movie was released in the United States as ''A Fistful of Dollars'' and is known by that title -- not by ''For a Fistful of Dollars,'' which is a translation of the Italian title.
1822447.xml.title: Corrections

1816165.xml.text: The Film entry on Sunday in the Week Ahead report of Arts & Leisure about a Robert Altman retrospective gave an incorrect address and phone number for the theater, IFC Center. It is at 323 Avenue of the Americas, at West Third Street, Greenwich Village -- not at 209 West Houston Street, South Village. The number is (212) 924-7771.
1816165.xml.title: Corrections

1819120.xml.text: An article in Business Day on Dec. 23 about the costs to acquire the gifts listed in the carol ''The 12 Days of Christmas'' misstated the gift for the 12th day. They are drummers drumming -- not the lords, who leap on the 10th day.
1819120.xml.title: Corrections

1816601.xml.text: An article and a headline in some copies of Business Day yesterday about plans by Samsung to introduce new rear-projection televisions next week at the Consumer Electronics Show misstated the technology the TVs will employ. They will use digital light processing, or D.L.P. technology -- not liquid crystal display or L.C.D. technology.
1816601.xml.title: Corrections

1821828.xml.text: A map last Saturday showing parishes affected by the reorganization plans of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York misidentified a Bronx parish scheduled for closing. It is St. Anthony's at 4505 Richardson Avenue, in the northern part of the borough -- not St. Anthony's at 1496 Commonwealth Avenue, in the central Bronx. A corrected version of the map can be found at www.nytimes.com/2007/01/20/nyregion/20churches.html.
1821828.xml.title: Corrections

1822661.xml.text: A classical music entry in the Listings pages of Weekend on Jan. 19 misstated the history of the performance in New York of ''Il Signor Bruschino,'' by Rossini, which the Gotham Chamber Orchestra is performing through Saturday. The Gotham Chamber Orchestra's production is the first professional staging of the work in New York since 1933, not the first staging since then. (The error was repeated in a Week Ahead entry in Arts & Leisure on Jan. 21, in the Listings pages of Weekend on Friday and in a review of a performance on Saturday.)
1822661.xml.title: Corrections

1817857.xml.text: A chart last Wednesday with the continuation of a front-page article about links between education and longevity misstated a correlation. People with more education are more likely -- not less -- to have had at least one alcoholic drink per month.
1817857.xml.title: Corrections

1816765.xml.text: An article last Saturday about mourning for Gerald R. Ford in California misstated the year he moved there after leaving the White House. It was 1977, not 1976. A correction in this space on Wednesday misspelled the name of the city where the Ford family lived. It is Palm Desert, not Palm Dessert.
1816765.xml.title: Corrections

1818668.xml.text: The 36 Hours column on Dec. 31 about London referred imprecisely to the term ''Cool Britannia.'' While it was used in the news media and advertising and was associated with the early years of Prime Minister Tony Blair's Labor government, Mr. Blair did not use it as a nickname for London.
1818668.xml.title: Corrections

1821830.xml.text: An entry in the News Summary on Thursday about plans by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to create a fourth major airport in the New York region by acquiring a lease to Stewart International misidentified the county where Stewart is located. It is Orange County, not Ulster.
1821830.xml.title: Corrections

1821339.xml.text: An obituary on Friday about the humor columnist Art Buchwald referred incorrectly to his novel-writing. ''A Gift From the Boys'' (1958) and ''The Bollo Caper'' (1974) were not his only novels. He also wrote ''Irving's Delight'' (1975) and ''Stella in Heaven: Almost a Novel'' (2000).  The obituary also misspelled the place of residence of one of his surviving children. Joel Buchwald lives in Culpeper, not Culpepper, Va.
1821339.xml.title: Corrections

1819116.xml.text: An article on Thursday about the death of three high school students and a school van driver in a vehicular accident in Freehold Township, N.J., misstated the given name of a friend of one of the victims, Michael Dragonetti, who said he was popular and respected by his classmates. The friend was Greg Lopez, not Michael.
1819116.xml.title: Corrections

1818493.xml.text: An article on Thursday about a Supreme Court argument in a labor case from the state of Washington misidentified the type of workplace at issue, in which employees who choose not to join the union must pay fees to support the union's collective bargaining. It is an agency shop -- not a union shop, in which all employees must actually join the union.
1818493.xml.title: Corrections

1819118.xml.text: A picture caption on Friday with an article about Staten Island Chuck, a groundhog being prepared for his first Groundhog Day duty, omitted a credit in some copies. The pictures of Chuck and his trainer, Douglas Schwartz, were by Chang W. Lee of The New York Times.
1819118.xml.title: Corrections

1821542.xml.text: Because of an editing error, an article in some copies on Jan. 14 about wealthy foreigners moving to Switzerland and negotiating tax breaks incorrectly described a formula used for determining a lump sum tax payment. The immigrants negotiate an annual payment based on five times the monthly rental value of their Swiss homes. They do not make a one-time payment based on the value of their Swiss homes.
1821542.xml.title: Corrections

1819117.xml.text: A list of holiday closings published Saturday and yesterday incorrectly stated the rules for New York City parking meters and the mail service in Connecticut today, Martin Luther King's Birthday. The parking meter regulations remain in effect; they are not suspended. Express Mail will be collected in Connecticut, but there will be no collection of other mail from street mailboxes.
1819117.xml.title: Corrections

1821544.xml.text: An article on Tuesday about sharp spikes in property taxes in northern Rockland County, N.Y., stemming from a settlement of $275 million that several municipalities and a school district agreed to pay to a power company as compensation for tax overcharges, misidentified the state agency that deregulated electric utilities in the 1990s. It is the Public Service Commission -- not the New York State Power Authority, which is an electricity producer.
1821544.xml.title: Corrections

1822106.xml.text: A review of New York books on Dec. 31, in appraising ''Water-Works: The Architecture and Engineering of the New York City Water Supply,'' referred incorrectly to the origin of the octagonal logo used by JPMorgan Chase & Company. Ivan Chermayeff, who designed the logo with Tom Geismar, said the design was intended to be distinctive and geometric; he said the design was not related to a New York water provider that was the forerunner to JPMorgan Chase & Company. The logo was not intended to resemble a cross-section of a wooden water pipe, and any such resemblance was not the decisive factor in the selection of the logo from several proposed designs.
1822106.xml.title: Corrections

1820097.xml.text: An article yesterday about a move by Bangor, Me., to ban smoking in cars where children are passengers misstated the population ranking of the city. Bangor is the third largest city in Maine, not the second. (Portland is the largest, followed by Lewiston.)
1820097.xml.title: Corrections

1821831.xml.text: An obituary on Jan. 9 about Momofuku Ando, the founder of the Nissin Food Products Company and the inventor of instant ramen, misstated his national origin. He was born in Taiwan during the Japanese occupation of Taiwan to Taiwanese -- not Japanese -- parents; he became a Japanese citizen after World War II.
1821831.xml.title: Corrections

1818320.xml.text: A picture credit with an article last Friday about visits to Atomic Age sites misstated the photographer's given name. He is Jeff Topping, not Jess.
1818320.xml.title: Corrections

1822443.xml.text: An article in Business Day last Monday about the pornography industry releasing movies in high-definition DVDs misspelled in one instance the name of a director who commented on the benefits of the new technology. It is Robby D, not Robbie D.
1822443.xml.title: Corrections

1819952.xml.text: An article in Business Day yesterday about a decision by an appeals court to strike down a Maryland law that required companies like Wal-Mart to spend more on employee health care misidentified the state's attorney general, who has two weeks to appeal. He is Douglas F. Gansler -- not J. Joseph Curran Jr., whom Mr. Gansler succeeded earlier this month.
1819952.xml.title: Corrections

1821338.xml.text: Because of a production error, the Sector Snapshot chart on the Market Gauges page in Business Day last Thursday, showing the price performance of a selection of stocks over one week and one year, gave incorrect results for these companies: On Jan. 4, Costco's performance was -1.0 percent for one week; +5.8 percent for one year; Jan. 5, Maxim Integrated Products, +3.6 percent and -13.5 percent; Jan. 6, Hewlett-Packard, +2.5 percent and +43.5 percent; Jan. 9, Hewlett-Packard, +1.9 percent and +38.8 percent; Jan. 10, AT&T, -5.1 percent and +35.7 percent; Jan. 11, Freeport-McMoran, +5.3 percent and -12.7 percent; and Jan. 12, Convergys +1.7 and +56.
1821338.xml.title: Corrections

1816355.xml.text: A picture credit on Dec. 26 with the Books of The Times Review, about ''The Girl With the Gallery: Edith Gregor Halpert and the Making of the Modern Art Market,'' by Lindsay Pollock, misspelled the surname of the man whose estate holds the copyright to the picture of Mrs. Halpert. He was Louis Faurer, not Fauer.
1816355.xml.title: Corrections

1822653.xml.text: An article on Friday about groups that planned an antiwar march in Washington on Saturday misstated the prominence of one labor group, the Service Employees International Union, which provides organizational and financial support for the group Americans Against Escalation in Iraq. The service employees union, which says it has 1.8 million members in the United States and Canada, is not the largest labor organization in the country; the National Education Association, which describes itself as a professional employee association that represents 3.2 million teachers, is the biggest.
1822653.xml.title: Corrections

1818855.xml.text: An article last Sunday about Blue Nile, an online diamond jewelry company, referred incorrectly to its relative standing among companies that sell the most diamond rings in the United States each year. Although jewelers do not provide comparable statistics about diamond-ring sales, Blue Nile does indeed rank behind Tiffany & Company. It also ranks behind at least one other competitor, the Signet Group, which operates Kay Jewelers.  The article also referred incorrectly to Mondera.com, another online jeweler. It is still in business; it is not defunct. And the article misspelled the city where the Zale Corporation, the jewelry retailer, has its headquarters. It is Irving, Tex., not Irvine.
1818855.xml.title: Corrections

1820100.xml.text: An article in Business Day on Dec. 29 about concessions that investors in oil and gas fields have given the Russia government misspelled the name of one gas field involved. (The error also appeared in articles last year on Nov. 8, Oct. 11, Sept. 23 and March 22.) It is Kovykta, not Kovytka.
1820100.xml.title: Corrections

1819304.xml.text: A sports article on Jan. 5 about the trade that sent pitcher Randy Johnson from the Yankees to Arizona referred incorrectly to the college degree held by Russ Ohlendorf, a player the Yankees received from the Diamondbacks. He has a degree in operations research and financial engineering, not economics, from Princeton University.
1819304.xml.title: Corrections

1816599.xml.text: A picture caption on Wednesday with the continuation of a front-page article about the hiring practices of Google reversed the names of the two employees looking over a job application. Laszlo Bock, a Google vice president, was at right; Todd Carlisle, an analyst at the company, was at left.
1816599.xml.title: Corrections

1819016.xml.text: A list of holiday closings published Saturday and yesterday incorrectly stated the rules for New York City parking meters and the mail service in Connecticut today, Martin Luther King's Birthday. The parking meter regulations remain in effect; they are not suspended. Express Mail will be collected in Connecticut, but there will be no collection of other mail from street mailboxes.
1819016.xml.title: Corrections

1819956.xml.text: A television review in Weekend last Friday about ''24'' misstated the method the president's sister uses to destroy personnel files sought by the F.B.I. She deletes them from a computer; she doesn't shred them.
1819956.xml.title: Corrections

1822446.xml.text: An article in The Arts on Wednesday about the coming release of a ''Lord of the Rings'' multiplayer online game misstated the size of Middle-Earth in the game. It is 50 million square meters, not acres.
1822446.xml.title: Corrections

1818666.xml.text: A picture caption on Dec. 31 with an article on restaurants in El Paso, N.M., and Ciudad Juárez, Mexico, misstated the name of a restaurant in Ciudad Juárez. As the article noted, it is Martino, not Marino.
1818666.xml.title: Corrections

1816359.xml.text: A front-page article on Saturday about adult children who take care of their aging parents referred incorrectly to expenses for the care of a spouse that are tax deductible if they exceed 7.5 percent of adjusted gross income. They are medical expenses, not any expenses.
1816359.xml.title: Corrections

1818351.xml.text: A dance entry in the Listings pages of Weekend last Friday about Complexions Contemporary Ballet, which is at the Joyce Theater this week, misstated the date its engagement ends. It is Sunday; it did not end yesterday.  The entry also misidentified the choreographer whose work is set to the music of Marvin Gaye. He is Dwight Rhoden -- not Desmond Richardson, who is a choreographer and dancer who runs the company with Mr. Rhoden. And the entry included an outdated reference to a new work by Nicolo Fonte. The program was changed and does not include that work.
1818351.xml.title: Corrections

1820104.xml.text: An article in Business Day on Dec. 29 about concessions that investors in oil and gas fields have given the Russia government misspelled the name of one gas field involved. (The error also appeared in articles last year on Nov. 8, Oct. 11, Sept. 23 and March 22.) It is Kovykta, not Kovytka.
1820104.xml.title: Corrections

1817235.xml.text: The ''Living In'' article last Sunday, on the Stuyvesant Square neighborhood, referred incorrectly to the Manhattan Comprehensive Night and Day High School. It is public, not private. The article also misstated the school's hours. It is open 9 a.m. to 11 p.m. on Monday through Thursday, 9 a.m. to 8 p.m. on Friday and 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. on Sunday.
1817235.xml.title: Corrections

1821945.xml.text: An article on Jan. 14 about a new spate of films with ensemble casts, misstated the year ''The Towering Inferno,'' another ensemble film, was released. It was 1974, not 1977.
1821945.xml.title: Corrections

1821550.xml.text: A chart in Business Day last Friday about recommendations by industry and environmental groups on how to limit greenhouse emission misstated a goal of the coalition. The group wants to cut greenhouse emissions to 20 to 40 percent of current levels by 2050, not 60 to 80 percent of current levels.
1821550.xml.title: Corrections

1822655.xml.text: A front-page article on Saturday about a breakthrough by Intel in chipmaking misidentified the site of a vast automated factory where the development effort took place. It is in Hillsboro, Ore., not Beaverton.
1822655.xml.title: Corrections

1818985.xml.text: An article in the special Education Life section last Sunday about the large percentage of Asian students at the University of California, Berkeley, attributed an erroneous distinction to the state. Hawaii -- not California -- was the first state without a racial majority.  Also, an article about financial aid for graduate students misstated eligibility for federal PLUS loans. Graduate students may indeed apply for the loans; they became eligible in July 2006.  And an article about rigorous high schools misstated the student newspaper job held by Prateek Kumar of Phillips Academy, who talked about his challenging courses. Mr. Kumar is deputy managing editor of the Phillipian, not the top editor. (Stephen S. Blackman is the editor in chief.)
1818985.xml.title: Corrections

1820300.xml.text: An article last Sunday about the new Seattle sculpture park misstated the year another institution, Benaroya Hall, home to the Seattle Symphony, opened. It was 1998, not 2002.
1820300.xml.title: Corrections

1818695.xml.text: An article last Sunday about choreographers and copyrights misspelled the given name of a lawyer and Merce Cunningham board member. He is Allan Sperling, not Alan.
1818695.xml.title: Corrections

1821082.xml.text: An obituary and headline on Thursday about Betty Trezza, a pioneer of women's professional baseball, misstated her age. She was 81, not 82.
1821082.xml.title: Corrections

1817866.xml.text: An obituary on Friday about Vincent Sardi Jr., who owned and managed the Broadway landmark Sardi's restaurant for more than half a century, misstated the year in which he was on Okinawa as a member of the Marines helping to supervise a rest camp. It was 1945, after United States forces had taken control of the island, not 1943.
1817866.xml.title: Corrections

1819957.xml.text: A report in the Personal Shopper column yesterday in House & Home, about the Americana at the Piers antiques show (55th Street and 12th Avenue), gave incorrect dates for the show. It will be open tomorrow and Sunday; it does not open today.
1819957.xml.title: Corrections

1821548.xml.text: A picture credit with an article on Sunday about criticism of the pace of an investigation into a crash in which a New Jersey State Police car struck a minivan in September, killing two teenage sisters, misidentified the source of one of two photographs. Only the picture on the right, of a memorial to the victims, was by Laura Pedrick for The New York Times. The other picture, of the victims and their mother, was provided by the family.
1821548.xml.title: Corrections

1816167.xml.text: An article on Saturday about mourning for Mr. Ford in Palm Dessert, Calif., misstated the year he moved there after leaving the White House. It was 1977, not 1976.  An obituary on Thursday about former President Gerald R. Ford misstated his relationship to the three brothers with whom he was raised. They were his half-brothers, not his stepbrothers.  Correction:  January 6, 2007, Saturday  An article last Saturday about mourning for Gerald R. Ford in California misstated the year he moved there after leaving the White House. It was 1977, not 1976. A correction in this space on Wednesday misspelled the name of the city where the Ford family lived. It is Palm Desert, not Palm Dessert.
1816167.xml.title: Corrections

1821825.xml.text: A picture in some copies on Sunday about a 10-alarm fire that gutted a block of buildings in Elizabeth, N.J., carried an erroneous credit. It was by Aaron Houston for The New York Times, not Colin Archer of The Associated Press.
1821825.xml.title: Corrections

1821835.xml.text: An article in Weekend on Jan. 19 about the film ''Waitress,'' which was shown at the Sundance Film Festival, misidentified the role played in ''Mission: Impossible III'' by Keri Russell, the star of ''Waitress.'' She was a protégée of Tom Cruise's character, not his love interest. (That role was played by Michelle Monaghan.)
1821835.xml.title: Corrections

1820940.xml.text: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about efforts in Congress to pass legislation to curb carbon dioxide emissions misstated a comparison of the two measures. A bill introduced by Senators John McCain, Republican of Arizona, and Joseph I. Lieberman, independent of Connecticut, which would tighten controls gradually and include subsidies for nuclear power, is more draconian, not less, than a proposal by Senator Jeff Bingaman, Democrat of New Mexico. Mr. Bingaman's bill would put a less stringent cap on emissions and includes a clause that would free industry from the requirements under certain circumstances.
1820940.xml.title: Corrections

1821340.xml.text: An obituary on Dec. 26 about Frank Stanton, the former president of CBS, overstated his role in efforts to persuade Congress to suspend an ''equal time'' law so that the 1960 presidential debates between John F. Kennedy and Richard M. Nixon could be broadcast. Spokesmen for NBC and ABC testified in support of Mr. Stanton's effort; Mr. Stanton alone did not persuade Congress to suspend the provision.
1821340.xml.title: Corrections

1819115.xml.text: An article on Wednesday about faculty opposition to a proposal to make Southern Methodist University the site of President Bush's presidential library misstated the venue in which Brad Cheves, the university's vice president for development and external affairs, commented on the debate. He was interviewed after leaving a campus meeting, but not the faculty meeting where objections were raised.
1819115.xml.title: Corrections

1822657.xml.text: A film review in Weekend on Friday about ''China Blue,'' a documentary about life inside a bluejeans factory in China, referred incorrectly to its clients. Levi Strauss does not buy jeans from it.
1822657.xml.title: Corrections

1818983.xml.text: An article in the special Education Life section last Sunday about the large percentage of Asian students at the University of California, Berkeley, attributed an erroneous distinction to the state. Hawaii -- not California -- was the first state without a racial majority.  Also, an article about financial aid for graduate students misstated eligibility for federal PLUS loans. Graduate students may indeed apply for the loans; they became eligible in July 2006.  And an article about rigorous high schools misstated the student newspaper job held by Prateek Kumar of Phillips Academy, who talked about his challenging courses. Mr. Kumar is deputy managing editor of the Phillipian, not the top editor. (Stephen S. Blackman is the editor in chief.)
1818983.xml.title: Corrections

1822833.xml.text: A sports article on Sunday about Indianapolis Colts Coach Tony Dungy gave the incorrect name in some copies of the city where one of his former assistants now coaches in the National Football League. Rod Marinelli is the head coach in Detroit, not Green Bay.
1822833.xml.title: Corrections

1819124.xml.text: An article in Thursday Styles on Dec. 7 about holiday music in retail stores and an article in Dining on Jan. 3 about the debate over playing music in restaurants misstated the name of a music consulting company that sells audio systems and programming to such businesses. It is DMX -- not Digital Music Express or Digital Music Xperience.
1819124.xml.title: Corrections

1822832.xml.text: A picture caption in Business Day on Saturday with an article about the extravagant 60th-birthday party planned for Stephen A. Schwarzman, a founder of the Blackstone Group, referred incorrectly to Katharine Graham's presence at Truman Capote's Black and White Ball, the New York social event of 1966. Mrs. Graham was the guest of honor; she was not simply one of Mr. Capote's guests.
1822832.xml.title: Corrections

1822662.xml.text: An article in Science Times on Dec. 29 about changes in medical practice over the past 50 years misstated the reason that sandbags were once used to stabilize the heads of patients undergoing cataract surgery. Sandbags were used partly because of problems with suturing, not to protect newly implanted lenses. This correction was delayed for research.
1822662.xml.title: Corrections

1816774.xml.text: A museum entry in the Spare Times listing of Weekend yesterday, about the New-York Historical Society, included an outdated closing date for an exhibition there. The exhibition, ''Elegy in the Dust: September 11th and the Chelsea Jeans Memorial,'' has been extended through July 1. It will not close tomorrow.
1816774.xml.title: Corrections

1819305.xml.text: The credit for a picture in some copies of SportsSunday on Jan. 7 with an article about a collaboration between the Giants and the Jets on a new stadium misspelled the photographer's surname. The picture of John Mara, the Giants co-owner, was by Evan Pinkus, not Pincus.
1819305.xml.title: Corrections

1822837.xml.text: An obituary on Dec. 18 about Herbert Gursky, an astrophysicist who studied the sources of X-rays from outside the solar system, referred imprecisely to some of these sources. A distant star he discovered is in the constellation Scorpius, not Scorpio, and the star was designated Scorpius X-1, not just Scorpius. The first recorded example of a black hole, which he and others discovered in 1971, was designated Cygnus X-1 or Cygnus XR-1 -- not just Cygnus. The errors were pointed out on Dec. 19 in an e-mail message that was misdirected within The Times. The correction was further delayed for research.
1822837.xml.title: Corrections

1820301.xml.text: An article on Jan. 7 about the lyricists' art misstated a word in a Stephen Sondheim lyric for the song ''Pretty Little Picture.'' The line goes ''And the boat and the boy and the bride are away,'' not ''And the boat and the buoy and the bride are away.''
1820301.xml.title: Corrections

1819709.xml.text: The Books of The Times review on Tuesday, about ''T. S. Eliot,'' by Craig Raine, included an erroneous reference in the book to the site where 14,000 people turned out in Minnesota to hear Eliot speak in 1956. It was Williams Arena at the University of Minnesota in Minneapolis, not a baseball stadium in that city.
1819709.xml.title: Corrections

1818854.xml.text: An article last Sunday about the NewYork-Presbyterian Healthcare System referred incorrectly to the history of hospitals that was chronicled in ''The Care of Strangers: The Rise of America's Hospital System,'' by Charles E. Rosenberg. The number of hospitals in the United States grew from only two in 1800, according to the book; there were not only two in the early 1900s. And a census of hospitals in 1909, not 1920, showed more than 4,300 hospitals housing more than 420,000 beds.
1818854.xml.title: Corrections

1820411.xml.text: A report on Jan. 7, about the Chiang-Colvin wedding, misstated the bridegroom's given name. He is Timothy Colvin, not Thomas.
1820411.xml.title: Corrections

1821547.xml.text: A picture caption on Wednesday with an article about Carmen Laureano, a Bronx woman who received money for clothing and furniture from The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, misidentified the subject of the picture in some copies. She was Luz Rivera, Ms. Laureano's 12-year-old daughter, not Ms. Laureano.
1821547.xml.title: Corrections

1820102.xml.text: An article in Business Day on Dec. 29 about concessions that investors in oil and gas fields have given the Russia government misspelled the name of one gas field involved. (The error also appeared in articles last year on Nov. 8, Oct. 11, Sept. 23 and March 22.) It is Kovykta, not Kovytka.
1820102.xml.title: Corrections

1818931.xml.text: The Streetscapes column last Sunday, about cornices on buildings on Broadway between 81st and 100th Streets, misstated the date for the construction of Haroldon Court, a building by Rouse & Goldstone at 90th Street. It was built in 1922, not 1912.
1818931.xml.title: Corrections

1821833.xml.text: A report in the Off the Dribble roundup on Sunday about the basketball Web site Truehoop.com misspelled the surname of the sportswriter who runs the site. It is Henry Abbott, not Abbot.
1821833.xml.title: Corrections

1817657.xml.text: An article on Sunday about marines charged in the killing of 24 Iraqis in the village of Haditha in November 2005 misidentified the Pennyslvania hometown of one marine because of information provided by his lawyer. The marine, Lance Cpl. Justin Sharratt, is from Canonsburg, not Carbondale. (The error also appeared in articles on Dec. 6 and Dec. 22.)
1817657.xml.title: Corrections

1816158.xml.text: A picture caption with an article on Dec. 27 about land that is being rented from farmers in Skagit County, Wash., to create a habitat for birds misidentified the birds shown on flooded land. They were waterfowl, not shorebirds.
1816158.xml.title: Corrections

1822448.xml.text: An entry in the Spare Times for Children listing in Weekend on Jan. 19, about the musical ''A Shelter in Our Car,'' at the Queensborough Performing Arts Center, misstated the name of the lead character. (The error was repeated on Friday.) She is Zettie, not Hettie.
1822448.xml.title: Corrections

1821335.xml.text: Excerpts yesterday from President Bush's State of the Union address misstated a word from the speech in some copies. Mr. Bush said, ''Some in this chamber are new to the House and the Senate, and I congratulate the Democrat majority'' -- not Democratic majority.
1821335.xml.title: Corrections

1822652.xml.text: An article on Jan. 22 about the likelihood that President Bush's State of the Union address would call for increasing the fuel efficiency of cars referred incorrectly to the use of a technology by American and Japanese carmakers to save fuel by shutting down some engine cylinders when they are not needed. It is American companies, not Japanese ones, that are the largest users. (The White House set a target of improving fuel economy by 4 percent a year, beginning in the 2010 model year for cars and the 2012 model year for light trucks, according to materials released with the speech.)
1822652.xml.title: Corrections

1819498.xml.text: A front-page credit yesterday with a picture of a march in Raleigh, N.C., in honor of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., misspelled the photographer's surname. He is John Rottet, not Rotter.
1819498.xml.title: Corrections

1821551.xml.text: A sports article yesterday about changes in the National Football League's testing program for performance enhancing drugs misstated the mandatory suspension for a player who fails a second drug test. It is eight games, not one year.
1821551.xml.title: Corrections

1821081.xml.text: A front-page article yesterday about the waning reliance of presidential candidates on public financing for campaigns included an outdated reference to Michael E. Toner, who said the 2008 election will be the most expensive in American history. As of Jan. 1, Mr. Toner is a commissioner of the Federal Election Commission. He is no longer its chairman, his position in 2006.
1821081.xml.title: Corrections

1822442.xml.text: A headline with an article in some copies on Dec. 24 about the death of three people in vehicular accidents in New York omitted one of the boroughs where a fatality occurred. Besides Brooklyn and Staten Island, there was a fatality in Queens. The article also misstated the sequence of events in the Queens accident. According to the police, a car driven by Steven Azconza of Westbury, N.Y., struck a car driven by Melvin Santana of Queens; Mr. Santana did not strike Mr. Azconza's car. The accident killed Mr. Santana's passenger, Wendy Almonte of Queens; an earlier version of the article misidentified the victim in that accident as the driver of the second car. A reader pointed out the error involving the sequence of events in an e-mail message on Jan. 16.
1822442.xml.title: Corrections

1819958.xml.text: An obituary last Friday about Maureen Orcutt, an outstanding golfer starting in the 1920s and one of the first women to become a sportswriter, attributed a distinction to her erroneously. She is not a member of the World Golf Hall of Fame.
1819958.xml.title: Corrections

1816592.xml.text: Because of an editing error, the Weekend With the Kids column last Friday about Ottawa misstated the cost in American dollars of the Capital Passport, an admissions package for museums in the city. The Passport costs $64.60 (or 75 Canadian dollars), not $88.50.
1816592.xml.title: Corrections

1819300.xml.text: An article and a picture caption in Business Day on Dec. 29 about an effort to persuade farmers to grow a low-linolenic soybean, which produces cooking oil with reduced or no trans fat, referred imprecisely to the qualities of the soybean. Oil from the low-linolenic soybeans has many of the same characteristics of regular cooking oil with less need for hydrogenation, a process that creates trans fat. Soybeans themselves do not contain trans fat.
1819300.xml.title: Corrections

1818344.xml.text: A picture on Sunday of members of the Coney Island Polar Bear Club, who protested the unseasonably warm weather by refusing to take a winter swim, carried an incorrect credit in some copies. It was by Andrea Mohin of The New York Times.
1818344.xml.title: Corrections

1822445.xml.text: A chart on Wednesday listing the youngest head coaches of the National Football League's modern era carried incorrect information from the Pro Football Hall of Fame about the age of Mike Tomlin when he signed with the Pittsburgh Steelers. He was 34 years, 10 months and 7 days old -- not 34 years, 11 months and 7 days.
1822445.xml.title: Corrections

1819499.xml.text: An article on Jan. 6 about White House efforts to find a new chief counsel misstated the working status of Laurence H. Silberman of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, who was considered a contender for the job. On Nov. 1, 2000, he took senior status, which allows a judge to continue to serve while handling fewer cases than a judge in active service; he has not retired. (President Bush has since named Fred F. Fielding to be the White House counsel.)
1819499.xml.title: Corrections

1822658.xml.text: A classical music entry in the Listings pages of Weekend on Jan. 19 misstated the history of the performance in New York of ''Il Signor Bruschino,'' by Rossini, which the Gotham Chamber Orchestra is performing through Saturday. The Gotham Chamber Orchestra's production is the first professional staging of the work in New York since 1933, not the first staging since then. (The error was repeated in a Week Ahead entry in Arts & Leisure on Jan. 21, in the Listings pages of Weekend on Friday and in a review of a performance on Saturday.)
1822658.xml.title: Corrections

1816604.xml.text: The NASD Trace Corporate Bond Data chart in Business Day yesterday misstated the dollar volume for trading in convertible bonds and for all issues. The volume for convertible bonds was $2.956 billion, not $4.155 billion; the volume for all issues was $18.817 billion, not $20.017 billion.
1816604.xml.title: Corrections

1819309.xml.text: A listing of credits in Weekend on Friday with a film review of ''God Grew Tired of Us'' omitted an editor and a producer. In addition to Geoffrey Richman, Johanna Giebelhaus edited the film, and Tommy Walker was a producer, along with Molly Bradford Pace and Christopher Quinn.
1819309.xml.title: Corrections

1820945.xml.text: A sports article on Sunday about off-the-field issues involving Tank Johnson of the Chicago Bears referred imprecisely to weapons charges to which he has pleaded not guilty. Johnson faces misdemeanor charges in Illinois because the authorities say that when they found weapons and ammunition in his home during a recent raid, he did not have the required state gun-owner identification card; Johnson has not been charged with possessing unregistered weapons and ammunition.
1820945.xml.title: Corrections

1818488.xml.text: An article yesterday about the Iraqi government's response to plans by President Bush to deploy additional troops referred incorrectly to Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki's absence from the government's news conference. Mr. Maliki was never scheduled to speak; it was not that he ''failed to appear.''
1818488.xml.title: Corrections

1820939.xml.text: An article on Monday about the drafting of President Bush's State of the Union address misidentified a speech three years ago in which he called for human exploration of Mars. Mr. Bush proposed that idea in a speech at the headquarters of the space agency, delivered on Jan. 14, 2004. He did not mention it in his 2004 State of the Union address, which was delivered on Jan. 20.
1820939.xml.title: Corrections

1818340.xml.text: A front-page article on Tuesday about a proposal by Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger to extend health care coverage to all of California's residents misstated a requirement for insurers. They would have to contribute 85 percent of premiums to health care services, not 85 percent of profits. The article also referred incorrectly to the precedent for universal coverage. California would be the fifth state, not the fourth, to try near universal coverage. (Besides Maine, Massachusetts and Vermont, Hawaii has also tried.)  A picture caption with an articleWednesday about efforts by Massachusetts to extend health care coverage to all residents reversed the names in some copies of two people who helped an immigrant from Bangladesh sign up for insurance. Feroza Bashar, a translator, was at right, and Goretti Macedo of Cambridge Health Alliance was at left.
1818340.xml.title: Corrections

1818494.xml.text: A map in some copies last Saturday with an article about the death of a 13-year-old boy who was struck by a Long Island Rail Road train in Queens showed two branches of tracks in Rego Park that no longer exist. A corrected version of the map is at nytimes.com/region.
1818494.xml.title: Corrections

1821076.xml.text: A chart with the Political Action column yesterday listing the estimated federal pensions of former lawmakers who have been convicted of crimes misstated the party affiliation of former Representative James Traficant of Ohio. He was a Democrat, not a Republican.
1821076.xml.title: Corrections

1820942.xml.text: A report in the Metro Briefing column on Jan. 5 about appointments by Gov. Eliot Spitzer of New York misspelled the given name of the deputy commissioner of the Office of Health Insurance Programs, a new position. (The error was repeated on Thursday in an article about the expected appointment of a new state health commissioner.) She is Deborah Bachrach, not Debra.
1820942.xml.title: Corrections

1821078.xml.text: A report in the Extra Time soccer roundup last Wednesday about reaction to the star player David Beckham's decision to leave Real Madrid for the Los Angeles Galaxy misstated the given name of Real Madrid's president. He is Ramón Calderón, not Raúl.
1821078.xml.title: Corrections

1821077.xml.text: The Market Gauges chart in Business Day on Saturday for the snapshot of Schlumberger, the energy services company, provided incorrect market and financial results. The stock, trading under the ticker symbol SLB, closed at $61, not $14.98. It had a 52-week high of $74.75, not $15.37, and a 52-week low of $54, not $9.57. The price/earnings ratio was 20.27, not 35.7, and the market cap was $72.12 billion, not $3.8 billion. The 12-month E.P.S. was $3.01, not $2.56, with a yield of 1.15 percent, not 2.2 percent.
1821077.xml.title: Corrections

1822656.xml.text: A music review on Saturday about Bob Seger, at Madison Square Garden, misstated the title of a Chuck Berry song he performed and its release date. Although the song is listed on a Seger album as ''C'est La Vie,'' and that title was on the set list for the performance, the song is ''You Never Can Tell.'' It is from 1964, not the 1950s.
1822656.xml.title: Corrections

1816159.xml.text: An article in Business Day on Saturday about possible ways to curb sharp increases in executive pay misstated the percentage increase in the value of a pension for Lee R. Raymond, the former chief executive for Exxon Mobil, because of bonuses from 2003 to 2005. It was a 50 percent increase, to $98.4 million from just under $66 million -- not 33 percent.
1816159.xml.title: Corrections

1819501.xml.text: A picture with a report in the Today in Business column in Business Day on Saturday, about the Ford Motor Company's plan to return to profitability, was published in error. It showed Herbert D. Kelleher, the chairman of Southwest Airlines who was named to the board of the Federal Reserve Bank in Dallas, instead of Alan R. Mulally, the chief executive of Ford.
1819501.xml.title: Corrections

1818346.xml.text: The Advertising column on Wednesday, about the popularity of penguin characters among marketers, misidentifed the agency that created a holiday commercial for Coca-Cola, based on information supplied by Coca-Cola. The agency was Berlin Cameron United, which previously worked for the company -- not Wieden & Kennedy, the current agency. The article also misspelled the surname of a founder of Club Penguin, a Web site for children. He is Dave Krysko, not Krisko.
1818346.xml.title: Corrections

1816596.xml.text: An article yesterday about the scene in Congress as Democrats prepared to assume control for the first time in 12 years, included an erroneous distinction for the late Ann Richards, whose photograph appeared prominently at a tea for Democratic women. She was not the first woman to be Texas governor; that was Miriam Ferguson, elected in 1924.
1816596.xml.title: Corrections

1821832.xml.text: An obituary on Jan. 19 about the humor columnist Art Buchwald misspelled the place of residence in Virginia of one of his surviving children, and a correction in this space yesterday misidentified that survivor. The town is Culpeper, not Culpepper. And it is Connie Marks Buchwald who lives there -- not Joel Buchwald, who lives in Washington.
1821832.xml.title: Corrections

1821084.xml.text: The DealBook column on Jan.14 in Sunday Business, about what some chief executives say during takeover battles, referred incompletely to the position of Delta Air Lines and its chief executive, Gerald Grinstein, on merger proposals. As the column noted, Delta has rejected a takeover offer from US Airways and says that it wants to come out of bankruptcy as an independent airline. Yet it has also been privately talking with Northwest Airlines. While Mr. Grinstein had not publicly commented on reports of the talks with Northwest until yesterday, he had indeed said that Delta had a fiduciary duty to consider all alternatives, including mergers.
1821084.xml.title: Corrections

1818984.xml.text: An article in the special Education Life section last Sunday about the large percentage of Asian students at the University of California, Berkeley, attributed an erroneous distinction to the state. Hawaii -- not California -- was the first state without a racial majority.  Also, an article about financial aid for graduate students misstated eligibility for federal PLUS loans. Graduate students may indeed apply for the loans; they became eligible in July 2006.  And an article about rigorous high schools misstated the student newspaper job held by Prateek Kumar of Phillips Academy, who talked about his challenging courses. Mr. Kumar is deputy managing editor of the Phillipian, not the top editor. (Stephen S. Blackman is the editor in chief.)
1818984.xml.title: Corrections

1818341.xml.text: A front-page article on Tuesday about a proposal by Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger to extend health care coverage to all of California's residents misstated a requirement for insurers. They would have to contribute 85 percent of premiums to health care services, not 85 percent of profits. The article also referred incorrectly to the precedent for universal coverage. California would be the fifth state, not the fourth, to try near universal coverage. (Besides Maine, Massachusetts and Vermont, Hawaii has also tried.)  A picture caption with an articleWednesday about efforts by Massachusetts to extend health care coverage to all residents reversed the names in some copies of two people who helped an immigrant from Bangladesh sign up for insurance. Feroza Bashar, a translator, was at right, and Goretti Macedo of Cambridge Health Alliance was at left.
1818341.xml.title: Corrections

1818497.xml.text: An obituary on Wednesday about Jane Bolin, the first black woman to become a judge in the United States, misstated the surname of the New York City corporation counsel who hired her as a lawyer in 1937. He was Paul Windels, not Windell.
1818497.xml.title: Corrections

1821903.xml.text: An article on Dec. 31 about winter events in St. Petersburg, Russia, referred incorrectly to the Cathedral of Our Lady of Kazan, the city's holiest shrine. It housed the Historical Museum of Religion and Atheism during the Soviet era. It was not mockingly called the Museum of Atheism.
1821903.xml.title: Corrections

1816157.xml.text: A front-page article last Wednesday about Iran's effort to exert greater influence in Afghanistan omitted a credit. Alan Cowell contributed reporting from London.
1816157.xml.title: Corrections

1821836.xml.text: A classical music entry in the Listings pages of Weekend yesterday about the Juilliard School's Focus Festival misstated the surname of the festival's longtime director. He is Joel Sachs, not Cohen.
1821836.xml.title: Corrections

1822108.xml.text: A report in the F.Y.I. column last week about a luminaire at Verdi Square misstated the given name of the director of art and antiquities for the Department of Parks and Recreation, who commented on the luminaire's history. He is Jonathan Kuhn, not John.
1822108.xml.title: Corrections

1818694.xml.text: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about the operetta ''The Beastly Bombing (or a Terrible Tale of Terrorists Tamed by Tangles of True Love)'' reversed two names. The librettist Julien Nitzberg was at left and the composer Roger Neill was second from left.
1818694.xml.title: Corrections
